item.title: SD IN FIVE: Directory of Learning and Performance Tools
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: There are so many educational technology resources available for teachers that it's hard to know where to start. UK-based site The Directory of Learning and Performance Tools is an outstanding resource because it surveys the entire landscape.  Jane Hart uses categories like "Instructional Tools" and "Document, Presentation and Spreadsheet Tools" to make it easy to find a specific resource. I almost want to keep this website my secret! Check it out. h/t Professor Leigh Graves Wolf at Michigan State University SOURCES: The Directory of Learning and Performance Tools

item.title: NEWS: The Future of Learning in a Digital Age . . . is Good
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
The Future of Learning in a Digital Age is an article by two Professors that is available for free online. As I read it I found myself nodding along to each of the author's points and contentions. It's spot-on. Here is what the MIT Press website says:
[The authors] focus on the potential for shared and interactive learning made possible by the Internet. They argue that the single most important characteristic of the Internet is its capacity for world-wide community and the limitless exchange of ideas. The Internet brings about a way of learning that is not new or revolutionary but is now the norm for today’s graduating high school and college classes.
Don't let this sound pedantic; it's fresh and helped me to understand why educational institutions may be slow to adapt, and what the characteristics of learning in a "digital age" may be. Read it, and tell me what you think about it.   SOURCES: The Future of Learning in a Digital Age (PDF)

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: Prezi for Zooming Presentations
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I created my first Prezi over the weekend about The Levels of Organization in Science. I put off its creation for a few days because I was intimidated: I thought it would be very hard. It wasn't. I created the following Prezi using creative-commons license photos through Prezi. It took less than an hour once I learned the ropes, which took five or ten minutes. Here is what Prezi has to say about their service:
Prezi is a cloud-based presentation software that opens up a new world between whiteboards and slides. The zoomable canvas makes it fun to explore ideas and the connections between them. The result: visually captivating presentations that lead your audience down a path of discovery.
Check it out and see what you think.
SOURCES:
Prezi
"The Levels of Organization in Science" Prezi

item.title: NEWS: Reduced-Price Internet Service from 'Internet Essentials'
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Internet Essentials is an awesome program from Comcast that offers reduced-price internet service to families. Internet Essentials is for "fast home Internet service for only $9.95 a month, plus tax," as well as the option to purchase a l0w-cost computer and to receive free computer and internet training from Comcast. There are no strings attached, except in order to qualify a family has to meet the following criteria:
  • Be located where Comcast offers Internet service
  • Have at least one child receiving free school lunches through the National School Lunch Program
  • Have not subscribed to Comcast Internet service within the last 90 days
Check it out for yourself. I'd be interested in seeing if my students could benefit from this program. If you've heard of or used Internet Essentials, let me know in the comments.
h/t Professor Sara Beauchamp-Hicks at Michigan State University
SOURCES:
Internet Essentials from Comcast

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: LogMeIn to Remotely Access a Computer
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
LogMeIn is a cloud-based service that allows remote access to a computer. With services like Google Docs and Dropbox, the need to access a computer that you're not physically near is not as crucial as it once was. Think about how using Google Docs allows you to edit the same project from any internet-connected computer. But, sometimes you just need to access something on one computer that you cannot otherwise get to, like a Mac-only app from your PC desktop. LogMeIn is an easy solution. It took me just a few minutes to setup:
  1. Create an account
  2. Download and install LogMeIn on the computer you want to remotely access
  3. Direct a browser to www.logmein.com to control the remote-location
h/t to my father Joel Rosenberg, who uses LogMeIn at his company SOURCES: LogMeIn

item.title: SD IN FIVE: Scribd is Super Easy for Embedding and Sharing Documents
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I uploaded the following PDF document of our Fall 2011 Soccer Program with Scribd - it's pronounced "skribbed" - which is "the world's largest social reading and publishing" platform. The Scribd website explains how users can "instantly upload and transform any file -- including PDF, Word and PowerPoint -- into a web document. I came across Scribd because I was unable to embed a Google Docs Document (quixotically, embedding a Google Docs spreadsheet or presentation is super easy - check out my post scheduled for 10-14 about Google Docs) Soccer Program 2011 I like Scribd due to the ease of sharing and collaborating through a hosted site, compared needing to upload, e-mail, and download the document. Students can access a document quicker because Scribd cuts out the steps of downloading and uploading a document. According to Scribd, "Millions of people come to Scribd every day to read and discuss business presentations, poetry, magazines and the latest best-sellers. Scribd acts as a hub for all your written content -- where you can upload, organize and distribute your work on the web and mobile devices." If you haven't already, I encourage you to check it out. SOURCES: Scribd The link to these and other resources can be always be accessed under the “Usable in Five Minutes” tab at the top of this page.

item.title: SD IN FIVE: Highlight a Tweet on Wordpress with Blackbird Pie
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: How do people make embedded-Tweets look great, without resorting to manually inserting a screenshot from Twitter? I discovered the quixotically-named Blackbird Pie, a plugin which does just that. Blackbird pie embeds a Tweet on Wordpress.com or self-hosted Wordpress blogs based on the URL, tweet-ID, or by searching a user's recent tweets. The next time you want to describe or highlight something from Twitter, you can embed the tweet by clicking on the blackbird icon from the Post screen. Here's an example of how I can highlight somebody's tweet with Blackbird Pie: [blackbirdpie id="120310804569538560"] SOURCES: Blackbird Pie Plug-in

item.title: SD IN FIVE: Need a YouTube or Other Video at School? Zamzar Works Well.
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I just discovered the website Zamzar, which allows you to easily convert and send files from YouTube, Google Video, Blip.tv and so on to your e-mail for download. For those of us with those websites blocked at work or school, Zamzar is great. At home, direct your browser to www.zamzar.com; follow the instructions below, and you'll be good to go. Be aware that after clicking "convert" the video will take from a few to approximately 10 minutes to arrive in your e-mail box. If you can plan ahead, Zamzar is a an awesome way to highlight videos for students that otherwise may not be accessible.
  1. Click on "Download Videos"
  2. Under Step 1 paste the URL of the video you want to download
  3. Under Step 2 scroll down to video formats and click ".mov"
  4. Under Step 3 type your e-mail
  5. Under Step 4 click convert!
h/t Mrs. Benita Clayton for telling me about Zamzar. SOURCES: Zamzar

item.title: NEWS: An Awesome Classroom Skype Conversation with New York-Based Show Me App
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
4th period Biology students and huddled together before lunch yesterday to meet with Kika, a representative of the New York-based startup company Show Me. Here's what she wrote:
Today I had the great pleasure of Skyping with Josh Rosenberg’s classroom in Shelby, NC. It was totally awesome! To give you some background, Josh is a High School Biology teacher and blogs on his site StudyDesigned. We met via the interwebs when he wrote a great post about how his 10th graders are using ShowMe! Talking to educators like Josh and his students is what really fires me up as the Community Manager at ShowMe because it reminds me of the real reason ShowMe is here: to make a difference in education every day. Talking to the class today reminded me that there is still TONS I can learn from classrooms and about what drives student inquiry. However, one thing that is constantly emphasized to me is that learning something new from another person is inspiring and it drives change.
How did this happen? Students used the Show Me iPad app to create written and verbal descriptions of topics in our unit - Cell Biology. I wrote a post here about their work, and sent an e-mail to Show Me to say, "look at our work!" Kika responded to the e-mail, we Skyped, and talked about how it might be interesting to have a classroom Skype conversation. We talked about using the app and how it may be improved, life in New York City, and what it's like to work for a start-up company.   My students were genuinely interested and engaged in the classroom Skype conversation. Thanks so much Show Me App and Kika for being interested in us and our work. SOURCES: Our Biology "Show Me's" Show Me on Study Designed Show Me

item.title: prcr: R package for person-centered analysis
item.dc:creator: zyztem
item.content:encoded:
I have been working on an R package for person-centered analysis. Here is a bit of information about it:

Background

prcr is an R package for person-centered analysis. Person-centered analyses focus on clusters, or profiles, of observations, and their change over time or differences across factors. See Bergman and El-Khouri (1999) for a description of the analytic approach. See Corpus and Wormington (2014) for an example of person-centered analysis in psychology and education.

Installation

Because this package is in development and is not yet available on CRAN, to install it, first install the devtools package using install.packages("devtools"), followed by the function devtools::install_github("jrosen48/prcr"). After installing the package, use library(prcr) to load it in each session.

Workflow and Use

The basic workflow is to first prepare the data (by removing incomplete cases and centering and / or scaling the data) with prepare data(), to create profiles with the create_profiles() function, calculate statistics about the profiles using the calculate_stats() function, and explore the distribution of profiles across select factors with the explore_factors() function. To review arguments and basic documentation for each function, call each prefaced with ?, i.e. ?prepare_data(). Here are brief descriptions of the functions:

  • prepare_data()

    • This function inputs a data.frame or matrix of at least two columns, as well as strings indicating the method of centering, the grouping factor (used only for group-mean centering), and the method of scaling. It outputs a list to be used in the create_profiles() function.

  • create_profiles()

    • This function inputs the list generated by the prepare_data() function, as well as an integer indicating the number of clusters, or profiles, selected a priori, the distance metric, and the linkage method. Its output is a list with two items, one for the output of the hierarchical cluster analysis, and one for the output of the k-means cluster analysis. <a href="test.com>test

  • calculate_stats()

    • This function inputs the list generated from create_profiles. It outputs a list with 10 items, including fit indices and a plot of the cluster centroids to be used in diagnosing the adequacy of the solution generated from the create_profiles() function.

  • explore_factors()

    • This function inputs the cluster assignments and the attributes indicating which cases to keep from the calculate_stats() function, as well as a data frame of factors to explore, a string indicating the specific factor to explore (or a vector indicating the factors to explore), and an optional vector of names for the cluster solution generated from the create_profiles() function.

item.title: Simulation as a way to make sense of scientific phenomena
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Over the past few weeks, I have read Winsberg's Science in the Age of Computer Simulation. It's an amazing book. Also, I've read Weisberg's Simulation and Similarity and Landriscina's Simulation and Learning. Each of these books is amazing and should be read. Together, I've started to think about simulation as way to make sense of scientific phenomena. These are, essentially, three in-depth explorations of the role of simulations in modern scientific practice. The thesis of each of these books is that computation represents a new way to make sense of scientific phenomena and the world. The core idea, that computers are central to what scientists do, is reiterated as a central feature of what scientists do across each of these philosophical books. This idea is not surprising. And yet, it presents a shift in how we think about science, the claims of science, and how science helps us make sense not only of scientific phenomena but also the world. Winsberg argues, essentially, Weisberg (not to be confused with Winsberg) argues Landriscina approaches this question from a more practical (and psychological) approach, arguing that there are two roles for computation.

item.title: NEWS: The Economist on Education
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I recall reading this a few months ago, and it caught my eye again because of its ranking of the school systems in many countries. Interested in a birds-eye view of what is going on in education worldwide? Here's what's happening.
Above all, though, there has been a change in the quality of the debate. In particular, what might be called “the three great excuses” for bad schools have receded in importance. Teachers’ unions have long maintained that failures in Western education could be blamed on skimpy government spending, social class and cultures that did not value education. All these make a difference, but they do not determine outcomes by themselves. Culture is certainly a factor. Many Asian parents pay much more attention to their children’s test results than Western ones do, and push their schools to succeed. Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea sit comfortably at the top of McKinsey’s rankings (see table 2). But not only do some Western countries do fairly well; there are also huge differences within them. Even if you put to one side the unusual Asians, as this briefing will now do, many Western systems could jump forward merely by bringing their worst schools up to the standard of their best.
SOURCES Reforming Education: The great schools revolution

item.title: NEWS: New Top-Level Domains Are Coming - Like www.yourname.pizza
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
A student told me that websites ending in "dot-pizza" might be arriving soon. This is fascinating and explains how top-level domain names (such as .com and .org) may be opened up to new options. Websites will be allowed to register under yourname.pizza or restaurant.newyork, instead of yourname.com or yourname.org. The NPR show All Things Considered explains:
The Internet, since its creation, has been largely ungoverned. But for practical purposes, the online world does have to agree on a Web addressing system. One global body with real power is the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, ICANN for short. And at a meeting in Singapore today, the ICANN board of directors changed website naming rules.
The change is due to ICANN's recognition that ".com" (commercial), ".org" (for non-profit organizations), or ".edu" (for educational organizations) are imited. Will this result in chaos? Not quite. An article I found on Mashable explains:
The option [new top-level domains] won’t come cheap, though: The application fee alone is $185,000, and the annual fee is $25,000. Still, we can imagine large corporations spending millions on these very soon.
Check out the NPR story for audio, and read more about the effects on Mashable. SOURCES: All Things Considered: Internet Governing Body Makes Major Change Mashable: ICANN Approves New Top-Level Domains, So Prepare For .Whatever

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: Want to Hangout? Investigate an Interactive Tour of Google+
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Google+ arrived with a bang and quickly took the early-adoptor technology crowd by storm. Now Google + is available to anyone (well, almost anyone: you must be over the age of 18) ready to sign up. The service fits nicely between a full-on blog such as Study Designed, and the rapid-fire discussions on Twitter. So, I've made a vow to augment my use of my favorites Twitter and Facebook with Google+. To that end, I recently came found an interactive tour that introduces five key features of the service. Here is a description of those five features:
  1. Circles: You share different things with different people. So sharing the right stuff with the right people shouldn’t be a hassle. Circles makes it easy to put your friends from Saturday night in one circle, your parents in another, and your boss in a circle by himself - just like real life.
  2. Hangouts: With Hangouts, the unplanned meet-up comes to the web for the first time. Let specific buddies (or entire circles) know you’re hanging out and then see who drops by for a face-to-face-to-face chat. Until teleportation arrives, it’s the next best thing.
  3. Instant Upload: Taking photos is fun. Sharing photos is fun. Getting photos off your phone is pretty much the opposite of fun. With Instant Upload, your photos and videos upload themselves automatically, to a private album on Google+.  All you have to do is decide who to share them with.
  4. Sparks: Tell Sparks what you’re into and it will send you stuff it thinks you’ll like, so when you’re free, there’s always something cool to watch, read, or share.
  5. Huddle: Texting is great, but not when you’re trying to get six different people to decide on a movie. Huddle turns all those different conversations into one simple group chat, so everyone gets on the same page all at once. Your thumbs will thank you.
SOURCES: Google+ Interactive Tour Google+

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: Google Spreadsheets and Presentations are Easy to Embed - Here's How
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I like using Scribd and will continue to do, especially for PDF files that are ready-to-view. But what if you need to make a change to a document hosted on Scribd? To make a change to the Soccer Program I uploaded in my post on Scribd, I had to edit the document and upload a revision, a process antithetical to the purpose and benefits of using a cloud-based service. I wondered if Google Docs allows embedding of their files, and indeed it does. The process of embedding a Google Docs spreadsheet or presentation is easy (Google Docs documents quixotically do not have the option to be embedded - you need to share the link instead). When you are ready to embed your spreadsheet or presentation:
  • Click the "Share" button at the top right of the page. C
  • Click "Publish/Embed"
  • Copy the HTML to a webpage.
If it is one page, then you will view it in its entirety; if it's more than one page, or a presentation, you can navigate easily between pages with the embedded controls. If only Google Docs would get it together about embedding documents this would be an indispensable feature for all of Google Docs services.   SOURCES: Google Docs The link to these and other resources can be always be accessed under the “Usable in an Hour” tab at the top of this page.

item.title: SD IN FIVE: Teachers' Domain for Free Videos
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I am fortunate to have access to United Streaming from the Discovery Channel, which is comprehensive and quite good. Teachers' Domain is another comprehensive multimedia resource - similar to United Streaming - but it offers free videos.  You can view up to seven videos before registering at the site, which is entirely free to do. There are abundant crummy video-resources websites out there. Teachers' Resource is not one of them - check it out and see if their content is useful or fun for you. SOURCES: Teachers' Domain United Streaming

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: Creating and Using Forms for Google Docs
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
One of my paths into using technology in the classroom was Google Docs, because it helped me to keep track of what I was working on during student teaching through UNC Asheville; between college, home, and the classroom I student taught in, e-mailing Word documents from computer to computer was tedious. Google Docs allowed me to create Documents, Spreadsheets and Presentations, each about as useful as the Microsoft Office or Apple iWork versions.  Soon after, I used my first Google Docs Form; they're great! Here is the form I used yesterday at our parent-teacher conferences for parents to sign-in. What can Forms do for you? Sign-in sheets, surveys, quizzes, checks for understanding, club and organization sign-ups, and event tests. Anytime you need to collect information online. All of the information which is submitted through the Form will go directly to a spreadsheet in your Google Docs account, which you can share and access anytime. You can easily switch between the "Live" Form, the Form you can edit, and the spreadsheet of submitted responses. So, you are not stuck with the first version of a Form you created. Create a Google Docs Form in Ten Steps:
  1. Click "Create" then "Form"
  2. Add a title (think: "Periodic Table Quiz" or "Parent-Teacher Conference Sign-in")
  3. Select what type your first question will be. There are seven types:
  4. Add help text, select whether the question is required (if so, the form will not be allowed to submit until the question is answered) and add answer choices if applicable
  5. Add any number and combination of the seven types of questions to your Form
  6. Select the theme of your form
  7. When you're ready, select "E-mail this Form" or "Embed"
  8. Embed the form in your website, or easier, add the link to the Form from your e-mail to your website
  9. To view responses just click on the title of the Form from your Google Docs homepage
  10. Edit the form anytime from the spreadsheet view by clicking on the menu item "Form" then "Edit Form"
You can create a short sign-in or quiz that is easy to use, looks nice, and collects information in an easy-to-access format in about ten minutes. Your form can ask for the respondent's name or be anonymous. I am on the lookout for ways that Forms might make collecting data easier, such as school-wide voting, student recommendations, or feedback on a team, event or organization.   SOURCES Google Docs

item.title: SD IN A DAY: Edublogs - Student and Teacher Sites and Blogs
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Edublogs runs Wordpress. This is great because Wordpress is the best way to create a website (or blog) and it is available to teachers and students in an easy-to-use format. Here is some information about Edublogs:
Since 2005, Edublogs has been hosting blogs and providing custom blogging platforms to individual teachers, school districts and hundreds of thousands of students. We’ve grown to become the largest, most trusted, best supported and widely used way for teachers and students to engage with the world of blogging.
Edublogs is entirely free for individual students to sign up. In addition to providing their service hey curate the edublogs awards; categories range from best group blog to best tweeter, and awardees are not at all limited to those who use edublogs. Some of my students have shown me work they created in their English class. Here are a few examples below. The author of Life in a Nutshell has promised to write a post here about his blog and what he likes about blogging.
  • Life in a Nutshell
  • Aubrey Ann F
  • Somebody has to say it
SOURCES: Edublogs.org The Edublog Awards

item.title: SD IN AN HOUR: Jing - Create and Share Screencasts and Screenshots
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Techsmith makes two products which I've used to create a screencast - which is essentially video of your screen with your voice narrating what you do and see. Jing and Screencast.com are those two products: Jing is a tool to record the screencast, and Screencast.com is used to manage and share those creations. I created the short screencast below to explain to students in my Biology class how to use Wallwisher for their research projects. The free version of Jing is really easy to install (I've done just that on my school and home computer, and laptop) and allows screencasts of up to five minutes. It also allows you to take and edit screenshots, to download immediately or share on Screencast.com - to which you can also link. Here is what Jing says about the use of their product for education:
Give your students the information they need, when they need it. Use Jing to record your feedback as you grade papers, or take a snapshot to share with your class. Your students can even use it to collaborate, or ask questions!
SOURCES Jing Screencast.com

item.title: GUEST POST: The Paperless Classroom with Mr. Jason Lineberger
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Jason Lineberger is an amazing teacher at my high school in North Carolina - he could teach me about any number of the tech-savvy tools he and his students use in his English classroom. His students talk about their work in his class before, during, and after mine!  I'm very happy that he agreed to write a guest post on "The Paperless Classroom" and how his students are using significantly less paper through their adept use of technology.  North Carolina Teacher Academy shaped me as a teacher, and unfortunately budget cuts have eliminated this organization.  Early in my teaching career I attended one of their week-long technology sessions, and the skills I learned inspired me to change my instruction.  Later I became one of the technology trainers for NCTA, working with Web 2.0 and 21st Century Classrooms, two of their training modules.  While I helped teachers around the state to reflect on the use of technology in education, NCTA allowed me to network with some of the most forward-thinking educators in North Carolina and beyond.  A weekend spent with Will Richardson pushed me to reconsider the value of traditional instruction.  Blogs like (Paperless Tiger) nudged me in the direction of experimentation, and ultimately my attempts to create my own paperless classroom. While I haven't freed myself of the paper chains, I have largely reduced my consumption, almost completely in my Honors English II course.  These students write their own blogs (through the Edublogs service) and submit work using our class wiki and by creating summative portfolios on Livebinders.  We respond to literature through blogging, podcasting, and web 2.0 applications, as well as through more traditional methods of discussion, presentation, and writing, though not usually on paper.  Like Tricia Buck's experiencemy class has become something less planned and more freeform.  I make certain we attend to all the standards, but we're not afraid to take some time to explore ideas.  The largest change in focus has been one of audience.  My students write for me, but they're also concerned with the larger audience for their writing.  When one student hit 5,000 unique readers on his blog, it became obvious to us that my small readership of one was much less important than his larger, world-wide audience.  This type of writing for publication carries more meaning, more value for my students, and it makes my class, for some of them, the most important class of the day.  And we do important work, thoughtfully, collaboratively, often asynchronously, and most often, paperlessly. Find additional information about Mr. Lineberger under the contributors page.

item.title: Incompetech - Generate and Print Graph Paper
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: When I didn't have graph paper for a laboratory in my Biology class, I searched online for something I could print. I found this website that has basic, printable graph paper. The site also has a whole lot more - from different square size to the width and color of the page border. item.title: SD IN FIVE: Wordle for Word Clouds
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Wordle has become very popular as a free resource. The site allows you to create a cloud of the most frequently used words in text or a website. The usefulness of a word clouds is in your ability to see what stands out - or doesn't - due to its prevalence in the text or site. To create a Wordle: 1. Go to Wordle.net 2. Submit text, or a link to the website whose text you want to use 3. Select the display options like how the words will be arranged, their color, and more 4. Save a picture of your Wordle by doing a screenshot, or embedding the HTML Below is a Wordle for Study Designed. That seems about right! SOURCES: Wordle

item.title: Personal - Technology and Magic
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I heard a loud bandsaw before I fell asleep last night. I waited until the clock ticked past 11:00 pm before giving up hope that it would stop. So I looked at the pack of earplugs I bought awhile ago, and inserted one into my ear. It quickly fell out. I grabbed a second and inserted it into my other year, this time holding it in as it expanded and blocked out noise. It fit perfectly. I inserted the other and it was silent. Peace!
I used earplugs before but never got it. They never quite worked and usually fell out within a few hours, or less. I didn't realize I was not using the plugs correctly. I didn't get it - I didn't apply that trick that made them work.
I am writing philosophically about "getting in" because of the application of this process to different aspects of living. How many things are a challenge, until a trick comes along that makes a difficult - or impossible - task appear easy. As I have grown from high school and through college and into my career, I see my acquisition of these tricks as my growing up. Learning tricks and life lessons on my own has been a challenge, but it offers me guideposts for how to live here and now: go there, over there, no, not there!
That technology entered my life at a point when I began to awaken to what is useful in my life is not coincidence; technology is itself a trick. Physicist Arthur Clarke wrote, "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic." Technology is timeless if it provides a solution to a previously aspect of life. It provides a trick.
My use of Google Docs instead of Microsoft Word is certainly not magic. But it's useful. Because of the people I have met and the connections I have made, I may say Twitter is magical. And the contact I have been able to maintain with my family on Facebook is invaluable. It helps me out. Messaging an aunt or uncle is so integrated into my life and consequently takes place with much greater frequency. We can drink from the well if we wish and read by candlelight when required, but plumbing and electricity are the magic of our choice.

item.title: Bloomberg EDU: A Radio Show and Podcast About Education
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Bloomberg is a media company started and run by Michael Bloomberg, the mayor of New York City. Bloomberg hosts many shows, one of which is Bloomberg EDU, the only nationwide radio show about education. That show has previously hosted Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, the director of education Vicki L. Phillips for the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, and superintendents from many large school districts. Because of an auspicious connection with a former college professor at UNCA, I'm going to be talking next week about technology and "what works now" for me as a young teacher with the host of Bloomberg EDU Jane Williams. I'll post when the show is actually broadcast (it's on XM and is syndicated on many radio stations) and will add a link to the podcast. In the meantime, check out the Bloomberg EDU podcast! SOURCES Bloomberg EDU Podcast Jane Williams on Wikipedia

item.title: NEWS: Let's Use What Students Use - Cellphones!
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I read this morning on the Innovative Educator blog about its author's article in the NY Times SchoolBook about the use of cellphones at school and in class. Schools do not generally allow students to use their phones in class. Some districts (like New York City) do not even allow students to bring them to school. Ms. Nielson of the Innovative Educator and Ms. Webb argue there may be a compromise:
Rather than pulling their hair out with the constant texting of today’s youth, more and more adults are getting on board and encouraging students to use their mobile devices as powerful learning tools. Across the globe, schools are moving from banning and fighting to empowering students in taking their texting talents to a whole new level by using them for learning, as well as using the devices to strengthen relationships with students and their parents or guardians. Of course, this does not mean simply lifting New York City’s ban on cellphones and inviting all students to bring their devices to school, take calls in class and text freely. Instead, by following some sensible guidelines and putting the right foundation in place, all schools can provide students with the freedom to learn with the digital devices they own.
Take a look at SchoolBook to read more and also check out Ms. Nielson's The Innovative Educator. SOURCES: The Innovative Educator Cellphones: Why Not Use Them to Teach

item.title: Short Entertaining DVDs about Science from HHMI
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: HHMI is a private, non-profit medical research institution based in Maryland. Their website is a repository of resources that always impress my students. Their DVDs on topics from "The Secret Life of DNA" (which made this science teacher for the first time truly understand the Central Dogma) to Science of Fat, and the well-produced magazine the HHMI bulletin. I can't state enough how excellent these videos are. They're like watching your favorite television show (since mine is the Big Bang Theory, I may be biased toward science topics - but these videos are awesome). For example, in an HHMI DVD titled The Double Life of RNA, an HHMI researcher explains how the discovery of RNAi illuminated how DNA really works for RNA, and that both must work in tandem for the DNA in a cell to be useful. Switching between molecular visualizations, the video animates the process with a castle and scribe (DNA), a secret message that exits the castle through a window, and chefs bobbing in the sea. When the secret message reaches the chefs, they cook whatever they're told. Sometimes RNAi, animated as a policeman, blocks this process - the chefs don't receive any messages and nothing is cooked. Students laughed at karate-chopping cop, asked questions about why DNA is protected in a "castle", and how whatever the chefs cook actually leaves the sea - how materials leave the cell. The reason I'm sharing this resource is because inexorably anything you order from the HHMI catalog costs very little. In fact, it's completely free, even shipping. As a student teacher I ordered half a dozen videos, and was amazed by their high-quality and lucidity in explaining complex scientific ideas. I couldn't believe they were free. I still don't. When you checkout with your order, which may range from one DVD to a dozen, other resources and a subscription to the bulletin,   SOURCES: Howard Hughes Medical Institute HHMI Catalog

item.title: A Virtual Compound Microscope from the University of Deleware
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Microscopes can be hard to come by, or those that are available to you are not great or in good repair. The virtual compound microscope from the University of Deleware is a good tradeoff. I picked an onion root tip, adjusted the lighting, rheostat (this determines how much light is allowed in), magnification, location of the slide, and the ocular lens, switched to the "Looking through the microscope" view and felt like I was back in my Biology classroom. I adjusted the coarse focus, then the fine focus, and felt frustration - similar to real life! -  at trying to view the slide correctly. Finally, I saw the cells in the root tip: Using a compound microscope is a great skill; however, they are challenging at first to use, and they might not be available. As a tutorial or tradeoff, this virtual compound microscope is a good choice. The link to these and other resources can be always be accessed under the “Usable in an Hour” tab at the top of this page. SOURCES UD Virtual Compound Microscope

item.title: Wikispaces - Create a Wiki and Wiki Pages
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
After I wrote about Wikipedia yesterday, I wanted to share my recent experience with creating a wiki with Wikispaces. My students conducted independent research, then met in the library to compile that research into a class wiki (here is that project on my class site). I learned a few lessons from the process and want to share those with you as well as information about Wikispaces. Wikispaces is essentially a custom-made Wikipedia, for schools, businesses and individuals. For our wiki any individual could edit any page. Creating student accounts or having students submit a request to join make the wiki more private, and allow everyone to see who has made a revision. Wikis belong at school because their use requires or informs the skills students already developed, are learning, or will be required to possess in college and at work. The term "21st century skills" has become an exhausted term in education, but the skills themselves are exactly what I am talking about. Using a wiki requires:
  • Collaboration: students must work together to successfully present a topic as a page within a wiki. For groups to be successful they must plan the layout of their page, and divvy up responsibility for their page. A lesson I learned: work asynchronously. If multiple users edit a page at once, Wikispaces cannot sort out what is overwritten: whoever saves their edit last will overwrite the other. So having users work on different pages, or on one page at different times, is crucial.
  • Adaptability: a wiki section may be complete, but not closed and finished. The nature of a wiki page - including those on Wikipedia - is to adapt to new information and events. Likewise, twitter streams, blogs, and electronic portfolios are adaptable. Working on a wiki requires students to ebb and flow with its development. Perhaps a student in a different group added content that is related to work by another; students should add a link. Within a group, students can adapt to the strengths and weaknesses of one another to complete the work on their topic.
  • Accountability: the product of student's work on a wiki is a completed section, page, or series of pages. Especially as part of a group or class, student's are accountable to their classmates and teacher. The proof is in their cohesive and complete work. Beyond being accountable to one another, students perk up when their work might be viewed by people in our community and beyond - suggesting that student's work on a wiki might be useful to other students within the same school or beyond can make students very accountable to producing quality work.
The service is free - if you're a K-12 or college teacher. I'm really excited about using Wikispaces for future projects in my classroom. SOURCES: Wikispaces

item.title: How to Use Wikipedia at School, and Wikipedia Resources
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I advocate for my students to use Wikipedia at school. It's certainly better than what students invariably end up on when starting research: the dark abyss that is Yahoo Answers or Ask.com. Like to "Google" has become synonymous with internet search, to "Wikipedia" something has become  coincident with looking up information on a topic. As I write this post I realize that my thoughts about Wikipedia have developed over a long time. As a high school student, I viewed the resource with a mixture of skepticism and curiosity. While in college, I saw Wikipedia grow. I remember the chair of my school's Biology department tell me to use it. He loved Wikipedia. As a college student, I used Wikipedia to learn about new things, to quickly find a fact, such as like the birthday of a famous person or data of an event, and as a jumping-off point for research. As a teacher, I use Wikipedia for student inquiries (How much does a Lion weigh? 350-400 pounds. What is Huntington's Disease? A dominant genetic disorder, to collect information for presentations and lectures, and for student projects, including research. One of the best compendiums about how to use Wikipedia at school specifically, and its reliability and validity generally, is ironically a Wikipedia FAQ page (I added the bold font). Here are a few of those important questions and answers:
Q: Can students cite Wikipedia in assignments? A: Wikipedia can be an excellent starting place for further research. Most Wikipedia articles contain an "External links" section at the bottom, which often leads to other relevant sites. Students can compare information in Wikipedia with information in other encyclopedias or books in the library. As a general rule, contributors to Wikipedia are encouraged to cite their sources, but, of course, not all do. Q: What prevents someone from adding false or misleading information? A: Wikipedia's content control mechanisms are reactive rather than preventive: anyone can go to almost any page and change the information to make it false or misleading.  Fortunately, such deliberate errors tend not to linger. Hundreds of dedicated Wikipedia contributors monitor real-time edit feeds (particularly for important or controversial articles) and quickly revert most inappropriate edits. Many articles are on one or more editors' personal watchlists (and major articles are watched by hundreds of editors), and this provides a second layer of content control. Third, Wikipedia's huge user base is constantly analyzing and improving every article, undoing vandalism as it is found. The key to this reactive system is that Wikipedia, unlike mainstream print sources, keeps a full history of every change to every article. Nothing is ever lost, and no abuse is permanent.
Another resource is from NC State University library, who produced a good and unopinionated video titled "Wikipedia: Beneath the Surface" which I play for my students. An even better resource, and an option for those who wish to mitigate some of the issues with Wikiepedia, is the verified, 5,500 article (equivalent to a 20 volume Encyclopedia) 2008/2009 Wikipedia Selection for Schools. According to that website:
Articles were chosen from a list ranked by importance and quality generated by project members. This list of articles was then manually sorted for relevance to children, and adult topics were removed. Volunteers then checked and tidied up the contents, first by selecting historical versions of articles free from vandalism and then by removing unsuitable sections
The key to using Wikipedia is to determine when its use is appropriate or best for a specific task. For brainstorming, use Wikipedia. To understand a topic and its connections to other topics, Wikipedia is without peer. To learn quickly about a new topic, or to check a fact, Wikipedia works wells. But if your or your student's goal is to write a research paper, Wikipedia is far from your best option. Researching what college to attend with Wikipedia is a recipe for confusion. And I would never use a Wikipedia fact against an expert opinion or to support an argument against a valid source. Like many educational technology tools, stakeholders should understand the benefits of Wikipedia and in what context it can be used best.   SOURCES: Wikipedia: FAQ/Schools Wikipedia: Ten things you may not know about Wikipedia Wikipedia: 2008/2009 Selection for Schools Wikipedia: Beneath the Surface

item.title: Googling Answers to the Test
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Professor Punya Mishra from Michigan State University wrote a post titled "All you can cheat, the web & learning" about cheating, and more specifically the use of the internet for exams and standardized tests. The article Professor Mishra refers to is about Denmark, which reasons:
The Internet is so much a part of daily life, it should be included in the classroom and in examinations." So several schools allowed high school students to use the internet on their year-end exams. Training students to master the art of sorting through heaps of information is one of the Education Ministry’s main goals in the project.
This type of thing is so antithetical to our current testing culture that I had to write share it here. I spend a lot of time as a teacher talking about, preparing for, administering, and reviewing results from the end of course exam in Biology. It's the main way my efficacy as a teacher is determined, and is the most important part of my student's grade. We need to bring our assessment closer to what we want from students. Our means (standardized tests) don't justify the ends - which is for students to become successful adults and members of society through school. It's good to read that others are discussing and considering alternatives for current standardized tests.

item.title: PERSONAL: Writing for Life
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
David Ray (D-Ray) Allen is a student at Shelby High School. David Ray was one of the students who shared with me his blog, and inspired me to write about Edublogs and its use a few weeks back. I promised then that one of the students would write about their direct experience: here that is. Thank you so much David Ray! High school is arguably one of the busiest times of life for the average American teenager. A time filled with the struggle to balance school, sports, and relationships. Sometimes the little things in life, like writing, fall down on the “to do” lists of us teens. Blogging has changed that. Blogging allows for teens around the globe the ability to write whatever we are passionate about. You don’t have to sit down in front of your computer and pull up Microsoft Word, and write your soul away and never share your work. This new concept of blogging allows for you to pick your favorite site, get a domain name, and write your heart away, for 2 subscribers or for 100,000 subscribers.
I’ve only been blogging consistently for about three months now, and it is the one time a week that I get really excited to write. When you grow up your teachers always teach you that cookie cutter way to write. Blogging allows for you to think outside the box, try your new ideas, and get feedback on them. Are you thinking about making a blog on your new favorite hobby of origami? Go for it. People will love it. Blogging frees your mind and soul to write. This new form of writing is a look into the future. Look around, whether you like it or not technology is changing this world. Sooner or later our schools will be paperless, handwriting will be an optional class that your seven-year old can take, and three-ring binders will be old news. Read more about David Allen on the contributors page, and check out his work on Life in a nutshell.

item.title: Missing The Point About Ed Tech
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
We don't yet understand the benefits and detriments of educational technology. Designing and implementing educational technology in schools is as hard as doing the same for a great lesson plan. Unlike an excellent lesson from an excellent teacher, we don't have many models - theoretical or role-model - to demonstrate how we should design and implement technology in the context of education. TPACK is one such model which places equal value on technological, pedagogical and content knowledge. We don't know if cell phones really can help students learn, or if students will just text one another until the next class starts. The results of this ed tech confusion are many:
  • A muddled message from schools, where our intentions in conflict with our policies and rules.
  • Expensive purchases of passing fads: SMART Boards and Flip cameras
  • Buying technological tools, products, or software when free alternatives are available
  • Blocking and banning efficient learning tools that we misunderstand
  • Missing a great opportunity to teach students on their own terms with their tools
We need to understand the benefits and detriments of ed tech, before we design and implement it in schools. Otherwise, we miss the point and might find more problems than solutions in educational technology.

item.title: Flubaroo - For Grading Google Docs Forms/Quizzes
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I've written before about my love for Google Docs forms. This week I wrote five questions for my Biology students to answer in conjunction with writing articles for an Organism Newspaper in the library. I finally used Flubaroo to grade those questions, and with a setup that took around 60 seconds it produced this: The orange area indicates the question with the least correct answers; only 38% of my students answered it correctly, whereas the others have more than 75% correct responses. I think this is a big time-saver that provides easy-to-view data about which questions students need more practice. Check out the overview and get started in less than five minutes with Flubaroo. SOURCES: Flubaroo Overview

item.title: Trending on Twitter: #pencilchat

item.title: Some Thoughts on Virtually Educated, by the NY Times Gail Collins
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
First things first, I'd like to welcome any new readers from my post Trending on Twitter: #pencilchat. Far more visited this site today than any before which is nice. I just noticed the article Virtually Educated by Gail Collins is currently the 4th most e-mailed article on the NY Times. I wrote about the NY Times before with my post the NY Times Squares Off Against Educational Technology. Here goes with the usually spot-on Ms. Collins:
O.K., here is my first question: Does full-time online learning really work for disadvantaged kids who may be alone at home all day? Kevin Welner of the University of Colorado did a review of all the information available on this and, in fact, on the entire question of how well full-time online learning works for kids in elementary through high school. The answer was: nobody knows.
I like this next line, because I'm sure it's true:
“The most detailed study is a couple of blog entries,” he said. Jim Shelton, an official at the U.S. Department of Education’s Office of Innovation and Improvement, said that he had not seen much rigorous research on the subject, either: “In fact, none that I am aware of.” Yet we are zooming forward as fast as new students can be recruited. I cannot help but suspect part of the impetus for this speedy transition is the profit motive.
Ms. Collins' editorial continues to describe how the for-profit company K12 Inc. replaced the existing virtual public school in Tennessee.  They rapidly grew enrollment and their profit, with little opposition and less research or evidence that their approach will help students. The essential problem isn't the absence of research on the efficacy of virtual public schools. It's thinking that anything technology-related (and even better if it is funded by an investment bank - Goldman Sachs - as is the case with K12) will instantly improve learning outcomes for students. It's missing the point about educational technology. SOURCES: Virtually Educated

Whatever your Christmas and Holiday plans, I wish you the best.

item.title: Nine things in 2011 - What did you ship?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Last year, Seth Godin wrote about 12 things he shipped:
Doesn't matter whether it was a hit or not, it just matters that you shipped it. Shipping something that scares you (and a lot of what follows did) is the entire point.
In this post I will do the same for my 2011 - here are eight nine of the things I'm proud to have "shipped":
  1. Created Study Bio with iWeb, then Study Designed (this site) and Study Rosey with Wordpress.
  2. Involved more than a half dozen colleagues, students, and friends as guest contributors at Study Designed.
  3. Finished my first and started my second year teaching Biology and Earth Science at Shelby HS.
  4. Became the faculty sponsor at Shelby HS for the Young Democrats club and began by coordinating volunteers for our fair booth at the Cleveland County Fair. Planned a canned food drive with the Young Democrats club, collected more than 800 cans for our community, and involved more than a dozen club members.
  5. Finished 80% of my MA in Education through Michigan State University - I'm concentrating in Technology and Learning and fell in love with educational tech primarily through my studies.
  6. Refereed 10 collegiate soccer games, as well as at the North Carolina Youth State Cup, which I hadn't done in over a year because of other commitments.
  7. Coached the Men's (Fall) and Women's (Spring) soccer teams at Shelby High School, but was not able to win a state championship like the Men did in 2010.
  8. Hiked, talked, dined, traveled, planned and loved Katie another year (this one is important).
  9. Met and made friends with amazing people online through Twitter, Facebook, and from Shelby, North Carolina to East Lansing Michigan and everywhere in between.

So I wondered how I could download then move my Facebook photos over to Flickr. I found a neat Mac and Windows app called photograbber that made it easy. Check it out.

item.title: Back! What work did you do over break?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I did a lot of digital cleaning - and a lot of actual cleaning - over break. Since you don't need to hear about the tidying of my classroom and home, I'll share with you some of the things I tidied up digitally, and for the upcoming weeks of school:
  • Wrote digital versions of the sample items for the North Carolina end-of-course Biology test in Google Docs, and compiled some review resources for students taking the exam at the end of the first semester later this month
  • I've been on Twitter since December, 2007, and have done a great job of following tons of interesting people. But, I haven't done a good job of unfollowing not-so-great people. I unfollowed around 150 accounts (from about 550 to just about 400) on Twitter and quickly felt a great weight leave my shoulders!
  • Unsubscribed more than a dozen feeds through Google Reader for the same reasons as with Twitter.
  • Organized my Dropbox folders - this is important not because I have all my files exactly where they belong, but because I know there's a system that makes some sense!
  • Backed up my websites, then saved the backups to my hard drive and Dropbox
  • Brushed up on Biology with my favorite Bio textbook
  • Prepared for a new unit in Earth Science (I've never taught nor studied the subject before) with a pithy Kindle book
  • Updated my to-do lists
  • Updated my calendars (I use the Reminders app with iOS)
  • Read through about three months of saved Instapaper content (I use ifttt  to  send starred Google Reader and favorited Twitter links there to read later, an awesome feature among many from ifttt)
  • Started a website for personal content at joshuarosenberg.me
  • Subscribed to new Podcasts including a new favorite, This Week in Tech, with the Downcast app 
  • Wrote two weeks of lesson plans
  • Reorganized my student and school site Study Rosey
  • Started using Evernote - I plan to use it for an MAED research project next semester
  • Used VidRhythm and had far too much fun with my family. Try it right now!
What work did you do over break? I know you didn't just sit around, eat lots of yummy food, and relax, right? Right? Follow me on Twitter @jrosenberg6432 and drop me a comment.

item.title: What I thought of my first iPad class experience
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This holiday break I wrote the four sets of sample questions for the North Carolina end-of-course Biology test into four Google Docs Forms and posted them to my class site. Our first day back, we reviewed a bit and discussed some new content, then made our way to the library to try two of the four sets of sample questions. Our librarian is great - she provided five new iPads to a group of students in my class. The rest of my students used library desktops. What happened next was magical and worth noting: My students have accessed my class website since the first week of school (some of them before that, because my back-to-school-night sign-in sheet was a Google Docs Form on the site). In order to properly use the site. you have to use Chrome, Firefox, or Safari - in other words, not IE. But, when I checked to see who had begun, my students on the library desktops had more problems than I could shake a stick at: two had network-login issues, half used IE and could not open the Google Docs Form, and others had trouble navigating to the website -such as trying to search for Study Rosey and having the results blocked (why Bing is the default search engine and why it is blocked are a mystery). My iPad students were halfway into the first set of sample questions before the majority of my library desktop students were where they needed to be. As a result, I don't think iPads are there solely to capture student's attention, as a gimmick, or as something for a school or district to hang its hat upon. They worked effectively as a tool in my class instruction. Because they are pared-down to the essentials (compared to a desktop or laptop computer) they streamlined my process of getting students working and learning. Also, I now recognize the difference between my use of an iPad (or student's tertiary use of it, such as when we recorded Show Me presentations) and to get student using a tool that works effectively. Plus, the mobile version of my class website looked great. I'm looking forward to using iPads again in a class setting.

item.title: Study Designed Podcast Episode 2: Ecology with 4th Period
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: My Biology students were interested in podcasting, so they wrote scripts and recorded a podcast, "Ecology with 4th Period". Subscribe to the podcast on iTunes or listen to it here by clicking on the name of the podcast above.

item.title: How long will a technology last? Of iPads and Microscopes.
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
The same students who successfully used iPads earlier this week used compound microscopes today.
Some used them beautifully, and were able to see root tips, cross sections of stems and leaves, protists and bacteria. A few students had trouble with the adjustment knobs and were unable to see their slides - and they were frustrated by that.
They remarked that at the middle school, they had brand new compound light microscopes that plugged in and lit the slide from below. This made them easier to use. Why buy new iPads when our microscopes don't work?
That remark made me stop. It's a good point. Microscopes have been used since the mid-1600s. They're still an effective tool for learning. iPads have been around since the Spring of 2010. How long each will remain a viable learning tool, in their current iteration, is a worthy question.
Every educational technology should be usable and effective, and the only metric that matters to determine which technology to choose for instruction is what works best at bringing students along in their understanding and application of knowledge, and their preparation for the world after school.
This post raised more questions than I'm prepared to answer or respond to, but I wanted to share my thoughts here at the end of a long day in my classroom. Thanks for stopping by!

item.title: Three Things I Believe About Tech
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
1. Mobile devices will become more common

It was tough to imagine giving up a desktop computer for a portable laptop - but we did. I'm sure we thought the same about the notion of a personal computer. I have a hunch that mobile devices - specifically phones and tablets, both which are becoming all-in-one-devices - are the next important learning tool. There are more mobile phones in Africa than in either Europe or North America - over 600,000,000. The $100 laptop never caught on because it was the wrong size. Mobile devices will become common in teaching and learning because they're useful and ubiquitous in our lives.

2. Technology will become less disposable

Our ability to own and use technology has grown exponentially. Because of that devices seem disposable; either implicitly or by design, even the best designed device I've owned - an iPhone 4 - seems to have a lifespan of about two years. Whenever something grows exponentially, it inevitably reaches a plateau and stabilizes. Then we realize that data, storage, cell phones and tablets are not infinite. Because of resources, cost, or even guilt, technology tools (including mobile devices) must become longer-lasting and less disposable.

3. Graphical user interfaces will become extinct

I grew up with a graphical user interface (well, my family's first PC was MS-DOS and so was command-based). A GUI is based on images, not text commands - think about all the items, tabs and applications on the desktop of your computer, tabs and windows in Windows or iOS, screens on ATMs, and even self-checkouts at the grocery store. There are alternatives. Voice is one - Siri is a game-changer. Gestures are another. We will be able to interact with devices in more intuitive, natural ways. Heads-up displays and augmented reality is another, and isn't so far off. GUIs will become extinct in favor of voice and gesture user interfaces. We will find it hard to believe we even got so good at typing away on our tiny iPhone keyboards.

item.title: Descriptions and dates of upcoming eclipses (NASA)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: My students asked me when the next solar and lunar eclipses were going to occur after our discussion Wednesday. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) publishes the NASA Eclipse Web Site. This is a great resource for finding when, where, and why eclipses will occur. There are two solar (Moon blocks the Sun), two lunar eclipses (Earth blocks the moon), and one transit (planet crosses between the Sun and Earth) in 2012. SOURCES: NASA Eclipse Web Site

item.title: #CES through a teacher's lens by Dr. Leigh Graves Wolf
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Leigh Graves Wolf just returned from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, and posted a great recap on her blog:
CES is an overwhelming experience.  Not necessarily overwhelming in the sense of multiple concurrent sessions and wanting to be in ten places at once (like SXSW) but overwhelming in the sensory department.  I went through each and every square foot of the north, central and south halls (I missed the hotel displays.) As I combed the halls, I was looking through my “teacher lens.”  Here’s a rundown of some of the great things I saw that have applications in learning environments:
Read more here.

item.title: Episode 3: Three Things I Believe About Tech Part One
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I woke up this morning ready to talk, talk, talk! Three Things I Believe About Tech (Part 1) is on why mobile devices will become more common in teaching and learning. After you listen - it's about three minutes - read about upcoming Part 2 and Part 3. Subscribe to the podcast on iTunes or listen to it here by clicking on the name of the episode above. Thanks!

item.title: How to Publish a Podcast in Three Steps
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Joseph Nabholz lives in Taiwan and asked  how we could set up a podcast so he could share stories and news with his family and friends stateside. This post has three parts: (1) What's in a name, (2) What you need to get started, (3) Recording and Publishing.

1. What's in a name

A podcast is a syndicated series of audio recordings that you can subscribe to specifically with iTunes. A podcast is a specific brand name for a syndicated audio recording subscribed to with Apple; thus, some podcast producers - like Leo Laporte of TWIT - refer to their recordings as netcasts. Wordpress and other blogging sites automatically create an RSS feed for all your posts. These blogging sites contains a servicet turns your posts into a format that is easy to syndicate to different sources, which can be Google Reader, another website, or in this case, iTunes. The type of syndication podcasts use is RSS (check out a handy one-page explanation here)  When you subscribe to a podcast on iTunes, it retrieves only the audio files from the RSS syndication feeds you subscribed to through iTunes. So when you add an mp3 file to your RSS feed via your website, you make it accessible to iTunes.

2. What you need to get started

  • A microphone
  • A computer
  • A program on your computer to record audio files -
  • A website to upload the files
  • A feedburner account

3. Recording and Publishing

Microphone: I use an inexpensive Logitech USB microphone that I bought on Amazon - it's worked great. Computer: I plug it into my Macbook Air. Program to record audio files: I use Garageband, but have been tempted to use the free "Charmingly Simple Audio Recording" software Piezo (if you use Piezo, let me know how it works). I recorded  I saved it, then exported it as an mp3 to my hardrive. Website: Here's the crucial step - I thought this would be the hardest part, but it's the easiest: upload the mp3 file into a post on your website. If you use Wordpress it's as simple as uploading a picture to a post. Feedburner: Go to www.feedburner.com and type in the address of your website. For help with setting up Feedburner, I refer you to this page once more.
Below is the main screen for my feed. Click the "Optimize" tab at the top, then click "SmartCast" to make your feed podcast-friendly (like adding the picture subscribers will see through iTunes, and select what category of podcasts yours belongs in).

Finally, you need to submit your podcast to iTunes. Here is a link to do just that through the Apple website; you can also submit your podcast from within the podcast section of the iTunes store in iTunes. You did it! If you have questions, please contact me at joshua@studydesigned.com.

item.title: Article in the Shelby Star
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I feel fortunate that my local newspaper chose to write an article about my class and the NSTA fellowship I received. Check it out right here at the Shelby Star: "Teacher has infectious love for science".

item.title: NSTA-Squared and Four Lessons So Far
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I applied to be an NSTA-squared member: that's a National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) New Science Teacher Academy (NSTA) member. I got in! So with the support of my school - and a cool article - I traveled to Indianapolis, IN this past Tuesday and will be here through Saturday evening. When I landed I felt something different. I was surrounded by science teachers - 10,000 of us. I waited for my green line bus to my downtown hotel and struck up a couple conversations. I was relieved within minutes. Teachers my age experience the same great things I've experienced the last two years. I met two teachers and a curriculum "coach" within my first 15 minutes in Indianapolis and was energized by those conversations. So, here's Lesson #1: If you don't plan to connect with someone again, you may not ever connect again! Exchange contact info. The following morning I attended a professional development institute (PDI). This is a day-long workshop on a specific topic - mine was the connection between science and literacy. Some "money" quotes: What types of questions teachers ask encourage types of understanding. Asking students to just observe something in science won't work - ask students to organize their observations and knowledge in order to get a richer response. Here's Lesson #2: Why do I do what I do as a teacher/professional? Reflection is important within the context of professional development. The NSTA agenda is overwhelming - its four books, each more than 250 pages. I downloaded each to my iPad and the ability to search for topics and workshop or presenter names has helped (I also saved a bunch of paper). And Lesson #3: Accept responsibility for your agenda. Overplan but if an event isn't going great, do something else. Teachers are great at sharing and offering their advice. I think the NSTA conference involves us really well - I can dissect a pig, use a telescope, or grow my own plant at various times throughout the day. I imagine that attendees can be even more involved as presenters. The NSTA conference is huge but there are regional and state science teacher conferences throughout the year. I'm thinking of ways I can share some of my expertise - with Google Docs, Wordpress, and social media in my class. Finally Lesson #4: Plan your own workshop. Note which topics and which speakers attendees gravitate toward and think about how you can get involved next year.

item.title: Applying to Grad School - 10 Steps
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I applied to three graduate school programs recently wanted to share some thoughts. This is for you - and for me to reflect. How to apply to graduate school in 10 steps: 1. Choose a specific subject area. Chemistry, English, and Education are broad. I had to search for a specific program, which only certain Universities or Colleges of Education have - educational technology. This made my search easier, because instead of hundreds of options, there may be a few dozen nationwide. In my case, only one school in North Carolina has an ed tech doctoral program. 2. Make a list of possible programs and locations. Include all possible programs - mine included a dozen schools from NC State to the University of Hawaii and Stanford. 3. Contact POIs. This is when your search will become concrete - send an e-mail or call the listed professor-of-interest (POI) for your list of programs. In many cases I received a response quickly. In others, I had to be diligent. When you speak with the professor express why you're interested in their program - it helps to know what interests you about their research. Then, say a few words about yourself. 4. Visit as many schools as possible. If you contacted your POI and the discussion went well, plan a visit to the school. This will communicate how serious you are about that program. It may also give you an (early) idea of how you will fit in and what your odds of admission are. In my case, I paid to visit the three schools I applied to. I've heard of departments paying for students to visit, but usually after admissions decisions were made in the spring. 5. Write resume. The program website should give you an idea of what the program is looking for. Some value undergraduate (or graduate) research or field-specific work. Tailor your resume to focus on your preparedness for graduate study - I think professors want to know well how you will fit in, whether you're ready to independently study and research, and make it through four years in their program. 6. Write personal statement. Each program I applied to asked me to detail my research interests in my personal statement. If I could do write mine again, I would begin with those interests. Professors are people too, and I think they would rather hear about my work and their research before my background and education. Think clearly and you will write clearly. 7. Inquire recommendation writers. Do this early. That way your recommenders can serve a informal advisors as well as recommenders. Some of mine responded with completed letters (or sent them to the program) in less than a week. Others took quite a while. Take this step seriously and consider it a mini-application -- I included versions of my resume and personal statements in my inquiries. Most people and professors will want to help you if they can tell you want to succeed. 8. Select a writing sample. I had a completed undergraduate research paper I used, but I had to do a lot of editing before it was ready - for example, I did a poor initial job with my APA citations and formatting. This is your chance to show your potential as a researcher or writer in graduate school. 9. Apply to 3-6 schools. This will take time, money, and energy. Do it early. Make sure everything is complete before the application deadlines, which in my case was in December. 10. Wait. This part was hard. I thought I would begin to hear from schools after the winter break - around January. That month turned to February and them the middle of March until I heard back about one application. Then a week later, I received an e-mail from another. Both programs informed me that I was going to be recommended for admission to the department, which would likely process the official notice within a few weeks. Don't be worried about this step - if someone tells you you're in, celebrate!

item.title: Quotes From My First Half at the NSTA Conference
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
As a blogger I've learned that I need to add value to your blog-reading experience. Otherwise you're gone! As I'm brainstorming about my time at the NSTA conference I've asked myself how I can add value to my experience here. Then, I can share that with you here. This is why science matters - but not according to me, but quotes from some of the events and workshops I've attended at the conference.
I make a point of talking science with passengers on my bus or airplane. If we don't do it, who will?
- Katie Hunt, former ACS President and Dow Chemical R&D sustainable technology director
Someone in line heard I'm a chemist and at the checkpoint asked me what my favorite chemical is. I said water. Another person in line said, "That's why we can't bring it through security!"
-Katie Hunt, former ACS President and Dow Chemical R&D sustainable technology director
I'm a chemist in part because my parents were chemists. But more than them, it is because my high school chemistry teacher. You never know how many students you impact.
-Katie Hunt, former ACS President and Dow Chemical R&D sustainable technology director
We are living in a time where life is rapidly changing. It all starts with space.
-Bill Nye, the Planetary Society
There are two preventable natural disasters: near-Earth-objects, and climate change.
-Bill Nye, the Planetary Society
When you see something the first time, it can provoke more questions than answers
Tim Samaras, National Geographic storm-chaser
We need to network, because not everyone is proud to be a teacher right now.
Tiffany McCoy, NSTA Jared Mader, EdTechInnovators, about the importance of changing Google search options Tune in soon for my "Second Half" quotes. Follow me on Twitter @jrosenberg6432

item.title: My 40 Most-Recommended iPhone and iPad Apps
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
1. Reeder - requires Google Reader. After Twitter, this is my most-used app.
  2. Instapaper - very good on the iPad. To make the most of it, setup an account with www.ifttt.com.
  3. How to Cook Everything - useful enough.
  4. Words HD Free - fun, syncs easily with Facebook.
  5. Find iPhone - I use this very often!
  6. Hulu Plus - costs money, but better than Netflix.
  7. Skype - useful.
  8. Downcast - great for streaming podcasts.
  9. Draw with Friends - you know its fun.
  10. Dropbox - enough said.
  11. Yelp - my favorite reviewing website.
  12. Temple Run - I'll admit it, I am addicted.
  13. Mint.com - great for tracking spending.
  14. Kindle - I've bought more than 50 books.
  15. Spotify - I like music again because of this.
  16. OnLiveDesktop - a complete Windows desktop suite. For free.
  17. Wordpress - well designed UI for Wordpress blogs.
  18. JotNot - scanner app, works amazingly well.
  19. Cleartune - tune in instrument accurately and quickly.
  20. GoodReader - access Google Docs files and manage them on your iPad.
  21. Evernote - great for everything from short notes to essay brainstorming (and essays)
  22. Pages, Numbers, Keynote - I'm continually amazed how well these are designed.
  23. iAnnotate PDF - import, export and manage PDF files.
  24. WolframAlpha - try it for everything from checking camps to comparing phylogenetic relationships among species.
  25. Twitter - not bad for a proprietary app.
  26. Mario Cooks - Mario Batali's really nice cooking app.
  27. Zite - I'm surprised by how great the content this app curates is.
  28. Khan Academy - rich content that's to-the-point and on-access.
  29. The Economist - favorite news source, requires subscription
  30. The NY Times - second favorite news source, requires subscription
  31. Flixster - awesome for finding out movie times
  32. GymGoal+ - put together and track weight lifting exercises.
  33. Instagram - easy to use, so you will use it a lot.
  34. Facebook - I use this app more than I care to admit.
  35. eWallet - keep track of passwords, works well and good UI
  36. TWC - the weather channel app, works well
  37. Sleep Cycle - tracking your sleep can be addictive.
  38. Clear - my favorite to-do list app, and I've tried a lot!
  39. Action Movie - try it at least once - fun mash-up movies you make in a minute.
  40. Photosynth - takes panoramic photos, great UI
