item.title: Quotes From My Second Half at the NSTA Conference
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Science matters - here are some quotes from some of the events and workshops I attended during the second half of the conference.
"Our debate is a healthy debate. It's a job. Ask a scientist if there's a consensus among scientific community, good scientist will say no." "Scientists have a hard time with the sea level rise conjecture. Modeling temperature is relatively easy, but predicting ice melt is hard." "Every time you had an ice age, you see higher iron levels in rock. This iron fueled biological processes." "These numbers puzzled me and led me on a five-year journey."
- Gabriel Filippelli, Professor of Earth Science at Purdue University
"Most Biology students are visual or kinesthetic learners. Research shows that Biology students often struggle with Chemistry, but do better than Chemistry majors in Organic Chemistry."
- Vernier Biotechnology workshop A few technology-focused quotes:
"Change the level of readability for Google searches based on your student's abilities." "So often I've seen Wordle used as a "Hey, look how cool this is?" - but teachers can use Wordle to pre-read science text." "You're the problem here! You have our third graders make chemistry websites, then my ninth graders use them for research." "If I do 'site:.gov' or 'site:.edu' look what happens" "Search Google for 'plate tectonics' then 'site:' in order to search within a certain website."
- Jared Mader and Ben Smith

item.title: It's Time to Change
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
“We can't solve problems by using the same kind of thinking we used when we created them.” - Albert Einstein
My professors at Michigan State University argue (wonderfully) in a short, fun video that we started in an agricultural economy, progressed to an industrial economy, and are now in a conceptual economy. But our educational institutions aren't quite there yet. We are preparing students for an industrial economy which doesn't exist!
"I think we're still preparing students for the industrial age. And that age is gone." - Punya Mishra "For too long we have focused on using technology. That focus has now shifted to integrating technology. But rather than using technology to do the same old things, what we need to do is think about innovating with technology." - Matthew Koehler
The solution is to adapt, and to begin to prepare students for the world we occupy. Thus the drive for 21st century skills such as critical thinking, collaboration, creativity and communication - look at our heroes: Steve Jobs, Sergey Brin, Mark Zuckerberg, Chris Dixon. I've been thinking about this strange suggestion, that teachers and learners should use phones - also known as smart phones or mobile devices - in order to learn. It seems crazy, which is the best sign of all that those people who say teachers and learners should use phones are onto something. Cell phones fomented an Arab Spring. The printing press fomented the Reformation Of course, the printing press (and its iterations) stuck around awhile. And, I think, so will mobile devices. It's time to think about how we are using technology. It's time to change.

item.title: Looking Back to Indianapolis: Three Posts from the NSTA Conference
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I enjoyed my time in Indianapolis for the NSTA conference. Here are the three posts I wrote during or after I attended: Quotes From My First Half at the NSTA Conference NSTA-Squared and Four Lessons So Far Quotes From My Second Half at the NSTA Conference

item.title: The MAED (and MAET) at Michigan State University:
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Two years ago I finished student teaching at Owen High School in Buncombe county. I had previously applied for the Master of Arts in Education program through Michigan State University. It was a good experience; specifically, the faculty and courses were outstanding, and completing the program prepared me for the next stage of my career. I'm thankful for the professors I learned from, the connections I made, the skills I learned, the background I acquired and the direction I'm heading as a result. To back up a step, there are two Master's degree programs at MSU - one is that which I completed, the Master of Arts in Education (MAED), and the other is a Master of Arts in Educational Technology (MAET). The MAED is entirely online whereas the MAET is available face-to-face, online, and through study abroad.

Because I'm interested in furthering my education in a doctoral educational or instructional technology program after my MAED, I gravitated toward coursework in the MAET during the second half of my degree. But, when I reflect back on my ten course sequence, each was meaningful throughout. The programs share many courses and faculty, but not the sequence of those courses and other details. I composed a portfolio of my work in the MAED at MSU right here on Study Designed. Check it out. Here is what is great about completing your master's degree at MSU:
  • I've been told multiple times during interviews in North Carolina that they look for graduates from MSU
  • The US News & World Report rankings might reflect the reputation of the college of education
  • There is a tight-knit community of educators and they have found a way to translate that community into an online degree
  • Your professors will possibly be more willing to assist you with coursework, advice, and letters of recommendation than those in an undergraduate program.
  • You'll learn to write, research, and apply coursework to your job - I saw this with my colleagues from other teachers to a academic coordinator for the NCAA.
I have never had an opportunity nor inclination (at least since elementary school) to thank a group of educators or a program of study until my experience in this graduate school - so, thank you to everyone from Dr. Leigh Graves Wolf to Mr. John Olle from a grateful student. Contact me via e-mail or Twitter if you want to learn more.

item.title: The New Math - Programming Resources
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I inquired a scientist (my brother) with the question, "Is computer programming today's version of geometry or trigonometry?" -- and he responded: "As someone in the applied sciences, the maths I know are different tools I can use to go approach a problem. Algebra is the brute force to rearrange, calculus lets you manipulate and shape object, trigonometry helps you align everything. Programming is much more powerful because it gives you a work force to apply all of these tools. The maths to be taught in conjunction with each other. You need basic mathematical skills to understand logical arguments and geometric layouts. However, their applications by hand are quite antiquated and you need computing and programming to do useful, real-life computation. To be most prepared students need to develop skills that everyone can't access, and be able to optimize their most powerful tool, computing. Those who can combine their understanding of mathematical tools with their application will do well. Programming seems like the best option."
I think he's onto something. Here are some resources if you are interested in learning more (like I am): Code Academy - Learn to code Udacity - Free classes, awesome instructors, inspiring community How to County (Programming for Mere Mortals) - Kindle Book

item.title: "It is easier to wash your hands than it is to design a first-rate online course"
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I was introduced last week to the Chronicle of Higher Education and a great article contained therein, "Innovations in Higher Education? Hah!" by Ann Kirschner: If you play video games, you will have no problem fantasizing that we could someday get to the point where online courses have a smidgeon of the immersive power of, say, Skyrim. But even in their still rudimentary form, and despite a self-selection bias (students sufficiently motivated to attempt self-paced online courses), those courses are already worthy alternatives to the classroom. In fact, a 2009 U.S. Department of Education study demonstrated that elementary and secondary students who took all or part of a class online did better on average than those taking the same course through traditional face-to-face instruction. Online courses are an important component of higher education's productivity tool kit, one of the few that offers an intellectually rigorous, measurable, and fiscally responsible way to serve more students while making better use of physical space. We could have tremendous impact by shifting first-year, entry-level courses wholly or mostly online, developed cooperatively but taught locally. Sounds radical, but it's a pretty old idea, put forth by Carol A. Twigg in 1999, and validated by trial programs over five years with 30 two- and four-year institutions. Her research documented that when institutions redesigned their large lecture courses, retention and learning outcomes improved, and costs went down. It is akin to hospitals discovering that cleanliness reduces bacteria and saves lives. However, it is easier to wash your hands than it is to design a first-rate online course. It takes a different skill from classroom teaching, and it is more expensive than chalk. It can be accomplished by faculty working in teams or in conjunction with experienced instructional designers who understand how to create large-scale projects like MOOC's huge, open online courses, which have been pioneered by Stanford and other universities. Check it out at the Chronicle for the rest of the story. Thanks Dr. Patrick Dickson for this lead.

item.title: The benefit of a tiny screen: Clear, RunKeeper, Reeder & Instagram
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I used to think my iPhone wouldn't be half as useful as my laptop. There are a couple reasons: the screen is small, the keyboard is small, and the processor isn't powerful enough.

But, when I think about some of my favorite apps, not only are they available on iOS (iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch), they're not available on iPad.

Clear, RunKeeper, Reeder & Instagram are all apps that are exclusively mobile - they're only available on the iPhone (or iPod Touch, or Android). This is because mobile app developers decided to take advantage of smaller screens, smaller keyboards, and smaller processors. Clear works because it's so easy to load, navigate, and check off to-do items. RunKeeper works because of built-in GPS and its easy-integration with Twitter, Facebook and the web. Reeder works (even better than Google Reader) because its intuitive, quick interface. Instagram works because it's pared-down. You're limited and that's wonderful. The lesson I take from this is that you (as an app developer, designer, educator, etc.) can design for any medium. The only requirement is that you understand what you're designing for. Then, take advantage of those things.

item.title: Accessing Tech at School: Problems & Suggestions
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Last year a colleague boldly stated, "If you ask them to text it, they'll do anything for you!". That may be true. With our students, however, asking them to use technology in different ways is hard. Here are some of the issues we face in my classroom in NC, and a few pithy suggestions:
  • Passwords: asking someone - especially a student - to remember a unique password will not be pretty. Either record for students or insist they write down their login information somewhere - this will save a bunch of headaches. Suggestion: have students use their Facebook password, or their lunch or school ID number.
  • Usernames: students broadly have difficulty generating unique usernames. Suggestion: Get them prepared before that task by showing good usernames (chelseaka2561) compared to bad usernames (chelsea atkinson) or very bad usernames (chels).
  • E-mail: many, many students do not have e-mail. This may surprise you - it surprised me! - and among those who do, many don't remember those passwords either. Headache. Suggestion: Try to sign students up ahead of time with teacher accounts, or services that do not require e-mail.
  • Internet Access: assignments which require internet access are primarily at-school assignments for my students, because not all of us have access at home. Suggestion: See if there's time in a computer lab or library at school for students to work monitored by a staff member, or hop on a computer beside them and get work done while they do the same.

item.title: Go with the flow: If This Then That for workflow
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
ifttt (it stands for "if this then that") keeps track of cool reads, links and recommendations that I might otherwise favorite, then forget. Workflow is a fancy-sounding name for what it does: in short, it automates things you normally do manually. There are many opportunities to leverage online services by connecting or making them work together. Some "recipes (The name ifttt gives to combinations of services) include:

Here are a few of my favorite ways to use ifttt: My tweets tagged with #fb automatically update my Facebook status  Instagram photos are automatically added to a Facebook album Favorited tweets on Twitter are automatically added to Instapaper Starred items in Google Reader are automatically added to Instapaper  Backup the content of Wordpress to Dropbox Check it out. And welcome to the future!

item.title: Blend the flip: two trends to last
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Among the trends in education - MOOCs (massive open online courses), big data, value-added measures, critical thinking skills, differentiated instruction, and so on - two stick out to me: blended learning and the flipped classroom. These ideas contain elements of teaching and learning that are true, and therefore have a chance of standing the test of time. First, some definitions: Blended learning: coursework is half online and half face-to-face Flipped classroom: content/lecture at home and activities/labs in the classroom The magazine Tech & Learning published 12 reasons to "flip your classroom" - flipping: helps struggling students increases student-teacher interaction changes classroom management can lead to a mastery program These are critical elements of a transformative education; these are things teachers need in order to bring along students of different abilities. Perhaps the future brings an double-swirled loop-de-doo educational experience (or whatever we will call our fads and obsessions). At this time, with today's students, and certain technological affordances, those who adopt blended learning might find the flipped classroom as the model that suits them best. Teachers might blend the flip for a tasty mix.

item.title: Eric Schmidt at BU commencement: You can write the code for all of us
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Eric Schmidt, former CEO of Google, gave the commencement speech Saturday for my younger brother's graduation from Boston University. I thought about my time on the plane to Boston: without wi-fi I responded to almost-forgotten e-mail, started Kindle books I purchased, and otherwise caught up with work. Some highlights:
Life is not lived in the glow of a monitor. Life is not a series of status updates. Life is not about your friend count. It's about the number of friends you can count on.
[Technology] is  a tool. You are the ones who will harness that power. And that requires innovation and entrepreneurship. Yes is a tiny word that can do very big things. Yes lets you stand out in a crowd.
It was an excellent commencement (replete with a bee attack) that we enjoyed. Watch it or read about it at BU today.

item.title: Facebook is (just) a service - be agnostic
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: A friend of mine wrote on Facebook "The new Google+ app is beautiful, but nobody is there." He is right about both. His statement made me wonder if and when we will be more open to moving between social network platforms. The age of one-network-to-rule-them-all (Facebook) will be replaced by Path or Google+ (okay, that's unlikely) or services that tap into already-existing social networks like Circle. The connections are there: it's time to sort, organize, then use them. Moreover, we are at a point in the development of our own social networks where our ability to connect with one another exceeds the capabilities of any one service or network. I say we pack our things and move to Google+ (that app is beautiful).

item.title: Today I organized my online world (with iThoughts)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Wikipedia describes a mind map as  "a diagram used to represent words, ideas, tasks, or other items linked to and arranged around a central key word or idea." So, today I organized "my online world" using the iPad app  iThoughts HD. It was easy enough to use. Here is the condensed version: The expanded version (warning: contains many "nodes") is right here - check it out.

item.title: I learned more than I taught at Shelby High
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This (teaching) all began with my science advisor at UNCA, back in 2008. He suggested I apply for a program for rising juniors interested in teaching math and science - the BWFund Scholars Program. It's similar in spirit to the NC Teaching Fellows and Teach for America in that it provides scholarships and stipends to teach in high-need areas (In the case of TFA, urban school districts and in the case of the BWFund, particular content areas). I started to teach Biology right after graduating from UNCA, at Shelby High School. Here are six of the lessons I've learned in Shelby: 1. Standardized tests do a decent job of determining student achievement. In my two years and four series of Biology EOCs, most of the time students who either a) work hard or b) are intelligent or a combination of both can succeed. Great teachers work with the students in the margins - they're able to get a student who might not succeed to do so and a student who might succeed to excel. I know a couple of these teachers in my department (shout out coming up). 2. But, standardized test culture damages school culture. In high schools in North Carolina, three subjects are assessed with an EOC: Biology, Algebra 1, and English 1. Focusing on test results gives us a reason to do things that are cruel: the processes of test preparation and test administration require superhuman focus, obedience and silence. Therefore, students aren't encouraged to critically think and reflect on what their knowledge means. We aren't affected so much when teaching and learning is already so rote and abstract; the damage to a school's culture is subtle because aiming at EOCs means we aren't aiming at those things which truly matter. 3. Being idealistic is good and even necessary, but idealism can come from an idealistic upbringing. The world is not idealistic (at least right now). I was as idealistic as a young person comes, and it's all a bit different now. 4. Planning and preparation aren't things on papers. Students know everything: planning was as much about the lesson as it was about who I was and what I felt each day. Therefore, teaching will transform you in order to be accountable to students who care and need you to care, too. 5. There aren't better teachers than those in classrooms. I've seen teachers do things at my school I've never seen before with dedication, talent and passion. Then I see them do it again and again, in the case of my department chair Lynn Pearson and my mentor Kim McDaniel, almost thirty years. I know my colleagues from UNCA, friends from high school, graduates in TFA and other young teachers face these same challenges. There isn't a superman (or superwoman) but some of the teachers working in classrooms right now. I've been lucky to know not one or two of them at Shelby High School, but dozens. A shout-out to my closest colleague Karen Simpson, who has higher standards for her students and herself than both can bare. You've taught me a lot. 6. There are so many artifacts that might emerge from a really strong teacher over a year. There isn't an easy way to assess the time teachers spend before and after school with classwork or groups of students, and it's harder still to determine the impact of one teacher on a few students. So, the most important work a teacher does is silent. These silent moments are why I'm different now and thankful for my two years in the classroom. From David Steeves on the soccer field to the parents in the community I've managed to learn more than I taught as a teacher. Thank you everyone in Shelby, especially my students, who put up with a quirky teacher and hopefully learned as much from me as I have from you guys.

item.title: A look into Department of Education/Ed Tech open education (stay away)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
The United States Department of Education Ed Tech Twitter account just posted a link to a story titled "The Power of Open Education Data." The first six paragraphs say, essentially:
Technology, data, and entrepreneurs can help with college affordability—as well as help address our national priorities in K-12 education. That’s why we are excited . . . to “liberate” government data and voluntarily-contributed non-government data as fuel to spur entrepreneurship, create value, and create jobs while improving educational outcomes for students.
Fair enough. The story then summarizes three things open data will enable: 1. The Education Data Community for comparing info about schools and higher ed organizations 2. Schools allow students to download to download their transcript and assessment data to " fuel personalized virtual tutorial offerings", such as enabling "them to create their own personal learning profile" 3. Create a "common trust" for schools to share data about students with other schools "and other qualified parties" I'm comfortable with the first - and quite uncomfortable with the second and third. Here's why. From #2: The personalized virtual tutorial offering feels like there's big money behind it. I see a lot of money being made hawking "personal learning profiles" to students with government money for limited utility. From #3: I think common trust means student data is about to get shared, in a whole new way, with companies ready to make money by organizing, comparing, and using data gained from student assessments, such as the EOCs here in North Carolina. Be weary.
I read a lot of ed tech news. Some things are good ideas whose time is almost here - such as digital textbooks. Other things are good ideas whose time is further along the horizon

item.title: Michigan
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
We're finally settled in after our big move from Shelby (where I taught high school) and Asheville (where Katie worked at the YWCA) in North Carolina to Okemos, Michigan.
Katie was offered a job as an after-school program coordinator with a good organization in Lansing – and I’m beginning PhD school at Michigan State.
Moving is stressful and I suggest against it - but if you have to, I hope you have friends and family who are half as supportive as ours were.

item.title: Code Academy is undervalued by an ∞ amount
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg

item.title: Little signs of big changes: Apple and Google
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes it's little things that give a hint about the direction of the big things. Nah, not like combing your hair or brushing your teeth (I suppose that's actually a medium-sized or big thing!). I'm thinking about Apple and Google, two of the largest (in the case of Apple, the largest by market capitalization) and most influential companies in the world. And I'm writing about why I believe one is headed in the right direction while the other is not.

The company heading in the wrong direction is Apple. I wonder about their latest evolutionary not revolutionary product releases, from iPhone 4S to Apple TV to iCloud. Some of the little reasons are like tips to me - something is not passing the smell test:

  • Leaving (and rejoining) electronics "green" standards EPEAT
  • Releasing Podcasts app
Now, I wrote Google off a few years ago; I know Gmail will stay relavent, but I didn't see anything exciting with search. I thought Google lost its ability to be innovative, and its slightly-messy role out of Google+ reinforced those types of thoughts. Slowly, I wonder if Google got its swagger back. I see some tips:
  • Making its newest tablet in USA
  • Being the first to the market with Project Glass
Google is hitting the right note with the little things, whilst Apple is making amateur mistakes. I think these are signs that some momentum for bigger changes is in place. And, I think my next phone may not be iPhone...

item.title: Superlative Times in Educational Technology
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
There's an article which is, at present, the #1 most e-mailed article on the NYTimes. It's about Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs). Here's an excerpt from that article, Universities Reshaping Education on the Web:
To date, most MOOCs have covered computer science, math and engineering, but Coursera is expanding into areas like medicine, poetry and history. MOOCs were largely unknown until a wave of publicity last year about Stanford University’s free online artificial intelligence course attracted 160,000 students from 190 countries. Only a small percentage of the students completed the course, but even so, the numbers were staggering.
The impulse to be excited about this - educational technology in general, the Times coverage, MOOCs - is easy. And much of it is deserved. I just wanted to plant a flag here, and say that the rapid rate of change in technology in general and educational technology, in this instance, specifically, might mean we're a bit too superlative.

item.title: EDUSING Day 1: Getting in
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I'm going to blog as much of my Singapore trip as possible: I'm calling it EDUSING and should get a lot of media (videos, pics) here soon.
I am in hour 15 of a 16 hour flight, from Newark, New Jersey to Hong Kong. To back up some steps, Katie and I drove from Okemos, MI to North Carolina, where I then caught a flight with our group to Newark. What's my reason for traveling?
Nine teachers and four staff are traveling to Singapore for 10 days. Each teacher is a Burroughs Wellcome Fund scholar (a program to incentivize teaching math and science); the staff are from either the Center for International Understanding (an international trip coordinator) or the University of North Carolina system.
Each teacher studied math or science as undergraduates and joined the Burroughs Wellcome Fund scholars program as juniors or seniors. Then, each of us began to teach in our content area - for at least a year. Finally, we expressed interest in an international trip together to interact with teachers and students in a different educational setting. For a number of reasons I don't yet know, they selected Singapore.
Here is what little I know about Singapore:
Diverse (Chinese, Malay, Indian and more) Wealthy (per capita GDP is greater than $50,000) Efficient - with a fetish for rules
I am capturing media - audio, video, and pictures - and am exploring how to share that. I have a friend who does video-blogging: his idiom is to walk while he records his content (it's pretty funny). I'll share some of my content once we settle down in Singapore.

item.title: Hamburgers and Ice Cream at Midnight
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Newark to Hong Kong lasted 16 hours. In that duration we consumed three (and a half) meals. Allow me an explanation.
We boarded at 4:00 pm EST. Pretzels and drinks came soon after we took off.
Dinner was at 6:00 pm EST - a chicken or beef, both which were stir-fry style. They came with a salad with a quarter egg, a wedge of lemon, and a piece of smoked salmon. They served drinks again, and I thought we were done for the night, until . . .
Midnight, EST was inexorably time for hamburgers and an ice cream cup. I had been sleeping and woke up to immediately start to eat. Then I fell asleep again, until . . .
Breakfast at 6:00 am EST - a choice of noodles or eggs. The noodles were more like dim sum (there were dumplings) and the eggs were an omelette with sausage.
We then landed at 8:00 am EST. I watched two movies, read a book, and wrote a while. It wasn't a bad flight!

item.title: EDUSING Day 3: Ministry of Ed and the National University of Singapore
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Today (it's now Tuesday morning, really early - don't ask) is our second "work" day in Singapore. Yesterday, we traveled to the Ministry of Education, as well as the National University of Singapore (NUS). The Ministry of Education (Wikipedia) is housed in a 24-story building by the water - it's gorgeous. We were led upstairs by a female guide, then met the director of international programs, an assistant director, and math and science curriculum experts. They led us through a two-hour discussion about what Singapore needs to improve, and what they do really well. I'll be adding notes later on, but wanted to just mention our trip there, now.
The National University of Singapore is one of the top research institutions in the world. They collaborate internationally with schools from Harvard to Duke to Oxford. I thought this exchange we had there yesterday was interesting: Q: Where do NUS students like most to study abroad or go for additional education? A: This is an easy question - America. Students unequivocally like their experiences and academics. Then the UK, Canada, New Zealand, and Sweden.
I'm compiling multimedia at this page on this site. Its a repository for my memories and experiences there. Check it out!

item.title: EDUSING Day 4: Morning Run and Dunman Secondary
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Michael and I awoke early and prepared for a quick, pre-breakfast run. We stepped outside our hotel and put in a good 30 minutes. Then, we hopped up the elevator to the rooftop pool and with the sun rising just above the skyscrapers around us we hopped in - an awesome start to a great day. We departed Dunman Secondary School in the west part of Singapore. This visit began to make some of my ideas about schools here concrete. My colleague Michael said afterwards, "The same message coming from schools comes from the entire country. In Singapore, students hear one sound." We are excited about teaching and learning because what goes on here: students care, teachers care, and society cares. On the other hand, I thought these schools would be radically different - they aren't.  I see the same basic schools, teachers, and even lessons. In fact, I saw a teacher doing this same lesson on infectious dieseases with her science class. I saw the same formative assessments, educational games, and even the same online stopwatch. The differences, I think, may come down to differences between culture. Everything here is about Singapore - things are streamlined from the ministry of education, through the (one) teacher education college, to each district and individual school. But, I don't know how we can get that - a different culture - nor if we even want to get that in the USA.

item.title: EDUSING Day 5: Mr. Low's App-Creating Class Using Game Salad
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: One of my favorite experiences in Singapore has been observing Mr. Low's class at Dunman Secondary School. Mr. Low used an iOS program with his students, Game Salad, and walked us through a tutorial he created for an app on North Carolina State Parks (in honor us our delegation). Take a look at the app they created in this video I created:

item.title: EDUSING Day 6: Two Themes from Singapore
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
This is about two themes from my time in Singapore:

There aren't shortcuts

When you're down as a gambler you want to get even. We have problems in the USA - and we are attempting to get even by doubling down again and again. We won't win with this strategy - we shouldn't talk about throwing out the system (educational, financial, health care). Singapore works with incremental change. They require buy-in: students and citizens need to see the benefit of small change. We love technology in the USA. Singapore likes technology - we ought to slow down and recognize that there aren't shortcuts. Technology won't solve our problems. And if we shouldn't believe technology will solve all of our problems: we need teachers, and students need school. Technology may revolutionize learning, but not overnight. We need buy-in from teachers and students.

Culture is key

It takes a long time to change culture. The culture in the USA is different from the culture in Singapore. We walked into classrooms in Singapore to a bowing chorus of students, "Welcome to our class, teachers." We won't do that in the USA. That's okay. Everything which occurs in school does so within our culture, therefore schools bear the brunt of the force of culture, both good and bad. My last day in SIngapore slurped noodles and then began to talk with others at a food court table. I talked about how I liked Singapore, and about why and with whom I was here. I asked what they liked about the USA, having been there: "People are able to say what they like." She did not qualify her comment. Singaporeans like our culture. We still have value. We do not need to imitate others' culture, but we do need to recognize the context culture brings to our schools and to work within our culture - slowly - to bring change.
I am surprised how similar and yet different Singapore is from the USA. We don't need shortcuts nor do we need a new culture. I learned from Singapore but also came to appreciate the USA more. At our final debriefing, we decided to add our thoughts on what we learned on our group site, Lessons From Singapore.

item.title: Lessons from Thailand
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: The lessons I learned from Singapore are like Singapore itself: tidy, organized, and sensible. The lessons I'm learning from Thailand are also representative of my broader experience here - they are all over the place! For example, Michael and I were taken advantage of in Bangkok by tuk-tuk drivers, travel agents, and merchants for t-shirts. It was confusing. But, when we left Bangkok for Krabi beach, we started to talk again and our mood lifted. We settled into our beach bungalow and rented scooters for the day, for $5.00. I felt happy and excited flying down a road to the beach. The lows in Thailand are low, but the highs are also high.

item.title: Our ability to connect is greater than Twitter/Facebook
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Earlier I blogged with Google+ in mind about how our "ability to connect with one another exceeds the capabilities of any one service or network." Listening to the podcast TWiG I heard about another new platform its founder created after feedback on his post What Twitter could have been:
As I understand, a hugely divisive internal debate occurred among Twitter employees around this time. One camp wanted to build the entire business around their realtime API. In this scenario, Twitter would have turned into something like a realtime cloud API company. The other camp looked at Google’s advertising model for inspiration, and decided that building their own version of AdWords would be the right way to go. As you likely already know, the advertising group won that battle, and many of the open API people left the company.
App.net asserts that "advertising-supported social services are so consistently and inextricably at odds with the interests of users and developers that something must be done." Just a few days after my friend Sam Harrelson wrote about A Day of Outages and Why I'm Sticking with RSS in response to Twitter buckling down its hatches (by cutting off third-party developers) I can relate to the developers moving to App.net. I think its move toward being more of a platform - owned by users - is a good direction. And I'm tempted to secure "@josh" before it's too late.

item.title: Life without iPhone: month one of an accidental experiment
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
During the last night I spent in Thailand at the end of EDUSING I lost my iPhone. I'm coming clean - I want to share what happens practically when you lose an iPhone, and to dive into what day-to-day life is like without a smartphone. The day before we began to head home (bus and a bunch of planes) my friend and I met some friends who were students at a nearby school. This was the kind of moment I traveled to experience. I prepped my things because the next morning we were departing for home. Everything I had was in a bag by the door to our room. Sparing you the details, I woke up, and my bag was gone. We contacted police who investigated, but basically, we had to go, and my stuff was probably taken by someone associated with the hotel. When we finally got back to the USA, I inquired my renter's insurance about whether property is covered - and whether it is covered internationally. It was. So that was a huge relief. When I got back to Michigan and commiserated with family we determined what was essential to replace - and my iPhone wasn't on the list. I went to Meijer and bought a hot flip device: I've used that phone since: almost a month. What happens to you and your lifestyle post-iPhone? Not a whole lot.
  • I check who I am working with and at what time and field through the browser on my iPhone. Now I print a list with all my assignments.
  • I use RunKeeper to track runs and bike rides. Now I use a watch and Google maps when I get home.
  • I find locations through the maps app. Now I plan ahead.
  • Finally, I walk around my house, hang out in the living room, and go to the bathroom (!!!) with my iPhone. Now I don't.
What is essential about a smartphone, or a phone? I did buy a phone - because text messaging and calling are awesome; a house phone and Google Voice require me to be home or wi-fi enabled, which is not always nor often the case. Those are essential features. I couldn't (this is not a first-world problem) live without them. TNW checked how many devices (14) and their cost ($1200) would replace the functionalist of an iPhone 4s. It's a great exercise in recognizing how many roles smartphones play in our lives. - losing mine has taught me better than any prescription or advice could that I don't need to always be connected. But I miss my iPhone and when the *new* iPhone arrives its temptation may be hard to resist!

item.title: I love to referee soccer
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I read part of the book The Mind at Work, in preparation for class:

This book made me think about why I love soccer reffing. I started in 2006 by registering then passing an exam, and starting out with the lowest-level, youngest matches. I got better with time. The author (a professor at UCLA and author of a good blog) made me think about why I continue to ref. Writing about waitressing: "The restaurant, then, provides the setting for one to display a well-defined set of physical, social, and cognitive skills." And hair styling: "[It requires] one's keen senses, and a developed physical rhythm." These reminded me why I hit the field with my whistle on a Sunday afternoon or Tuesday night. I feel at ease and confident when I referee. I gather from The Mind at Work there are numerous ways to get into the same type of flow and ease at work.

item.title: ideaplay exclusive: Some Tips for Keeping Track
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I wrote a post at the group blog for educational psychology and educational technology graduate students:
Some of us are on e-mail, watching, just waiting to reply. About as good are those who respond within a day – 24 hours. Then, if you’re like me, you respond, but your response is sometimes days or weeks later, and to to great surprise of your recipient. Finally there are those who lose e-mail, in a great pile of missed messages. Each of these examples occurs in my own inbox – there are some e-mails I get back to instantly and others which wait and ferment until their time is ripe.
Check it out over at ideaplay!

item.title: Tread lightly: advice to myself
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: A challenge I face is to have a light touch. I have the tendency to take off in one direction, with energy and passion. But I smother. I get messy. This challenge reminds me of advice for writers: writing is about what you leave off the paper.

item.title: Second-youngest delegate at the DNC: way to go Nick!
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Last year I had the pleasure of working with Nick as the faculty sponsor for Shelby High's Young Democrats. When he involved me it was to my benefit as much as other students. We were able to accomplish a lot as an organization, almost all due to Nick's passion. [caption id="attachment_2477" align="aligncenter" width="201"] Credit: http://clct.com[/caption] Because of his work at Shelby High, in Cleveland County, and throughout North Carolina, Nick is the second-youngest delegate at the Democratic National Convention. This is a huge honor and I'm proud of him. Some news stories among many about Nick: Gardner-Webb University Real Clear Politics WFAE First Post Creative Loafing Charlotte

item.title: I'm learning about data
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I'm in CEP 930, an intro to research methods. An early task is to record - each day - something of interest. I chose to record the number of minutes I sat down and meditated (at night). Anyhow, about once per week, I'm grouchy or tired and I don't achieve my aim of 10 minutes each evening. I noticed in learning and recording data I impact the underlying phenomenon. In other words, I never meditated with regularity until I kept track of it in a spreadsheet. Also, I think, sharing this type of goal and my progress toward it also impacts my results. It would not surprise me in the end that I'm consistent: I meditated (almost) every day! And all I did was create a Google Docs spreadsheet, CEP 930 Project. Kinda interesting to see some type of pattern beginning to form. I'll update again later in the semester...

item.title: Chicago teacher's union strike - thoughts
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I just read a cogent description of what's happening in Chicago, where teachers in the third-largest school district in the country began a strike last Monday. The strike is continuing through the beginning of this week, despite it appearing to end late last Thursday night and Friday morning. Alex Kotlowitz wrote:
Not only was the public confused, but so were the union’s members. One teacher told me last week that if you asked 30 of his colleagues why they were striking, you’d get 30 different answers. Their explanations varied: the teachers wanted respect, they opposed school reform, they feared the privatization of education (in the form of charter schools), they wanted to teach Mayor Rahm Emanuel a lesson. But I believe something else has been going on here, something much more profound.
The author spent time in a Chicago school, and quotes education historian Diane Ravitch (and supporter of public schools), to the effect that universal prenatal care was her priority for improving education. The Times continues:
In Chicago, 87 percent of public school students come from low-income families — and as if to underscore the precarious nature of their lives, on the first day of the strike, the city announced locations where students could continue to receive free breakfast and lunch. We need to demand the highest performances from our teachers while we also grapple with the forces that bear down on the lives of their students, from families that have collapsed under the stress of unemployment to neighborhoods that have deteriorated because of violence and disinvestment. And we can do that both inside and outside the schools — but teachers can’t do it alone.
Who do you trust to teach and to chart the direction of teaching and learning at school? According to this 2011 survey (Gallup), high-school teachers are the fourth-most honest and ethical people, behind nurses, pharmacists, and doctors. 62% of people ranked high-school teachers as "high" or "very high" for honesty and ethical standards [among other reasons - see comments].

Conversely, 7%, 18%, 19%, and 25% of people ranked members of congress, business executives, lawyers, and bankers "high" or "very high", by comparison. Yet, broadly, teachers are left out of the debate as to the nature and vector of the profession, while bankers are allowed to do as they please. There are factors beyond honesty and integrity which determine the ability for a group of people to determine what is best in teaching and learning. There's room for private business in education. But, consider who will still be around when reforms fail (Eager for Spotlight, but Not if It Is on a Testing Scandal).
Many of my heroes are teachers: I know this as a student and as a teacher. I think the only way to improve education is to encourage reform with the insight of the best teachers around - those in classrooms. I can't see any other option in the case of Chicago's teachers than what they've done (strike). In conclusion, I wrote a few paragraphs which seem relevant today, in a course by Dr. Kyle Greenwalt:
I refer one final time to "Science Teacher Doyle" who writes this week about a class trip. "For at least one day, I do not fret over my biggest classroom fear--killing curiosity." Perhaps in a society where our curriculum is muddled and our aims are obfuscated, I can cast away my fears about evaluations and test scores: my aim is to engage students with their education, to the extent that they grow into successful adults. So much of that transformation is necessarily personal and silent. I think this is part of the reason why it is so difficult to say what constitutes a successful curriculum.

item.title: Biking to work and the new year
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Rosh Hashanah is the start of the Jewish new year; 10 days later Yom Kippur is the end of the start of the new year. On Rash Hashanah Jews dip apples in honey and say thanks for a sweet, good year, then on Yom Kippur Jews ask for forgiveness, and to be written in the book of life once more. I hopped on my bike this morning and rode to work. It was awesome! Cool fall air and a six-mile ride. I'm thankful and wish that next year I may also ride my bike to work in the cool fall air, with the same friends and family that have made the past year great. [caption id="attachment_2522" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Image from the department of kinesiology at http://msu.edu[/caption]

item.title: Twitter: We "Pulled a Romney"
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: What does a social media company have in common with the Republican candidate for president? An API-centric Twitter could have been more powerful than Facebook today, but is headed in another direction by cutting off great developers and releasing crummy apps. Mitt Romney was recorded on a video which was released via Mother Jones stating his disregard for half the nation. So to "pull a Romney" is to make an unforced error, to tinker and mess with a sure thing. Both Twitter and Mr. Mitt Romeny's campaign serve as a good lesson of when it's better to walk lightly and act carefully; good things come along too rarely.

item.title: On old cleats: Nike Mercurial Vapors
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I didn't want to then, but I began playing soccer when I was six. Sometime around 10 I started liking Adidas, later specifically the Copa Mundial soccer cleat. I wore Copas consistently until a soccer tournament in the spring two years ago - because I bought the Nike Mercurial Vapors pictured here for about $60. They were the older version and were on closeout at a soccer tournament... I loved them. Yesterday, I had to say goodbye: they're falling apart after hundreds of days on my feet. So in this post I commemorate the first cleat I've loved which is not made by Adidas. And for a holiday present this year . . . I'm size 9!

item.title: So . . . What's Grad School About?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_2545" align="aligncenter" width="640"] Photo by Dr. David Wong[/caption] Grad school, in short, is what I hoped grad school would be. Grad school is quite different from teaching, which is itself quite different from both undergrad and grad school: not one among those is inherently more difficult than the other. And there's almost no way around the fact that the teachers I worked alongside in Shelby are, mostly, my heroes. Rather, each has particular challenges and things which come easy. So, grad school is:
  • Unstructured time . . . which is easily mistaken for a lot of free time, which it is not. Rather, there is always more to read and consider and do better and this is hard for any variety of perfectionist.
  • Hard . . . regardless of how I felt when I was told, "You'll feel stressed/at sea/inadequate" and I didn't believe it! The expectations for and among my cohort is higher than I thought, and I didn't expect anything average anyway.
  • Exciting . . . because things I didn't consider open doors to ideas and ways of thinking I didn't even know about.
Being around great people, from my professors and advisors to new colleagues and family and friends has made the ups-and-downs more up. Anyway, at this juncture, grad school is . . . great!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi my name is Sandra and I just wanted to drop you a quick note here instead of calling you. I came to your So . . . What’s Grad School About? – Joshua M. Rosenberg page and noticed you could have a lot more visitors. I have found that the key to running a successful website is making sure the visitors you are getting are interested in your subject matter. There is a company that you can get targeted visitors from and they let you try their service for free for 7 days. I managed to get over 300 targeted visitors to day to my website. Check it out here: http://ittsy.com/it/3x

item.title: I'm (still) learning about data: An update
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: So, I promised an update on my project for CEP 930, an intro to research methods. The task is to record – each day – something: I chose to record the number of minutes I sat down and meditated. A consistent pattern was beginning to form. Unfortunately, that pattern has been sketchy recently. Check the last week if you've been thinking, Josh seems a bit stressed recently . . . !

item.title: Sunday afternoon movie -- Jiro Ono
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Katie and I watched the movie Jiro Dreams of Sushi (it's available through Netflix, and has a 99% rating on Rotten Tomatoes) this afternoon. The movie is about the 86-year-old sushi chef, Jiro Ono, who is considered the best in the world. His restaurant relies upon the work of apprentices, who he teaches over 10 years. After that time Ono calls an apprentice a chef. Trusting someone in the long run is an investment. I sometimes need to be reminded that shortcuts never are and that big changes take awhile.

item.title: A big stack of books is a good thing
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: A little bit back someone asked me, "What are you reading?" and I did not have an adequate response. I said something about reading Bill Bryson's A Short History of Nearly Everything, which is a problematic answer because I've been reading that book for about nine years. But, I have started to read more, and I'm now at a point where I have acquired too many books. Yep, it's possible. Here are the books which Katie obligingly lets me stack next to our living room couch: How We Think by John Dewey Good Work: When Excellence And Ethics Meet by Howard Gardner The Mind's New Science: A History of the Cognitive Revolution by Howard Gardner The Signal and the Noise by Nate Silver Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software by Charles Petzgold The Problems of Philosophy by Bertrand Russell and, most importantly - How to Tell If Your Cat Is Plotting to Kill You by The Oatmeal

item.title: I learn slowly
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: The lady I love left me to spend the weekend with her folks in North Carolina. Consequently, I thought about learning slowly, and how for me this weekend represents that process. Today, I ate a whole order of dumplings from my favorite Chinese restaurant in three minutes flat. Yesterday I saw my high school buddies from Grand Rapids and Metro Detroit, and spent time with some new buddies, and played Fifa 2012 all weekend. I also recertified at the state soccer referee clinic. I did things I've needed to do (recertify) and have wanted to do for awhile (see Lee and Ryan). I also spent a night fixing Katie's Toshiba laptop and cleaning Katie's and my apartment. This is to say, I didn't do what I've always done, nor did I do what I do when my better half is here. And that's to say, I think learning is a two-steps-forward and one-step back process which is either slow or nonexistent. It's hard to know if you're on the second step forward, or on a different step back, and that's okay. I once thought I learned fast because of how well I could recite facts on tests. But, I now think I learn much slower. This year has been one in which I've grown very slowly. For that and those who took part in it with me, I'm thankful.

item.title: What do you think?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
One of my professors this semester said if you don't know what to say, look thoughtfully to those around you, and ask, "What do you think?" Then hold their gaze intently. It works!
This is not about that. Rather, this is about knowing what to think. Personally, this means doing what, to the best of my ability, is right.
It's easy to do what's right when things are going well. The value in doing what is right comes mostly from doing it when you don't want to. To be concrete, if you're well-fed you will find it easy to not steal food. When you're hungry, it's a different story. This post is a gentle reminder to myself to always do what's right.

item.title: A (brief) review of 2012
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
2012 was a great year!  This year was full of great moments for which I feel exceptionally lucky:
  • Ran a 1:34 half-marathon in Charleston
  • Had a great article published in the Shelby Star
  • Attended the 2012 National Science Teachers Conference 
  • Ran my first marathon in Nashville
  • Graduated from the Master of Arts in Education at Michigan State University
  • Proposed to the love of my life, Katie!!!
  • Traveled to Singapore and Thailand
  • Began PhD school
  • Learned slowly in PhD school - and that's a good thing
  • Spending the holidays and more time with my wonderful parents and brother
Some things which were challenging:
  • Moving from North Carolina, where Katie grew up and I lived for seven years
  • Missing science: teaching, learning, and loving the subject I studied for years
  • Leaving friends in North Carolina, who now feel like family

item.title: Deciding what not to do (thoughts from Steve Jobs' bio)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Note: Deciding what not do to (thoughts from Steve Jobs' bio) was cross-posted at IdeaPlay.  Check out IdeaPlay! The zen-like title of this post comes from Steve Jobs’ biography by Walter Isaacson. I read it over break, after *accidentally* taking a copy from my family.  There is much to learn from this detailed, interesting, rich book, but when someone asked me what I learned, I responded with one thing. What someone decides not to do is important.  To Jobs, what he didn’t do defined his simple, minimalist personal and professional style. An anecdote.  When Jobs arrived at Apple from his first departure, he cut programs for software and hardware, like a Palm Pilot-like device with a stylus.  He told his team, we’re going to make a laptop and desktop, with a consumer and professional version of each.  That’s all.

item.title: What's up with the weather?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I'm tossing my hat into the ring . . . 2012 Was Hottest Year Ever in U.S. Last night, I thought about both my and our collective inaction in the face of climate change. I attended Warren Wilson College, a very liberal college, for three years.  I transferred to the University of North Carolina Asheville, still liberal, though much less than Warren Wilson.  I taught high school and am now in graduate school at Michigan State University.  My personal trajectory has been from the far left of the political and social spectrum (Warren Wilson College) to rather mainstream (Michigan State University). I recognized that my views toward the climate are tied to my views toward liberalism.  It's hard to say, "I'm an environmentalist" because that view is, collectively, the same as saying "I'm a liberal." I hesitate to say that because it doesn't match my self-image.  I'm not a greenie. It's time to separate the individual and collective.  Protecting the environment is our priority, regardless of how we each feel about liberalism.  I think there's no time other than now to start - so I'm starting today.  The enormity of what to do individually and collectively shouldn't stop us from doing what small things we can. Changing my Twitter and Facebook profiles to identify with making environmentalism a priority won't do a thing, collectively, but I can't imagine a better place to start.

item.title: RSS bundle of a few favorite educational technology sites
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Leigh, Andrea, and Jodi suggested the following blogs to Punya's question, "What educational technology websites should I follow?".  You can subscribe to them as  the "EPET bundle" here, either through Google Reader (it prompts you to sign up - "Get started with Google Reader") or you can just use the link to read them. What's RSS and Google Reader?  See this post.

item.title: A more manageable MOOC (#etmooc)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I've followed Alec Couros as the massive open online course (MOOC) about educational technology.  The course title #etmooc, which both identifies the hashtag for Twitter importance of connections to the MOOC.  I briefly searched and found information about connectivism, a "learning theory for today's learner." I am compelled as I learn more generally about learning theories.  I am drawn to the situative perspective, which describes how thinking develops socially, and that how knowledge is used is tied to how knowledge is learned.  It is important to learn in meaningful ways that affect our lives.  I think connectivism and the situative perspective are related, and am interested in exploring their relationship by participating in #etmooc.
By way of introducing myself (that's the first assignment, along with connecting one's blog to the blog role - note the tag #etmooc to identify this post to the course's blog aggregator), I'm an online teacher for two awesome courses and a student in the educational psychology and educational technology (aka EPET) PhD program at Michigan State University. I was a high school biology teacher and soccer coach before joining EPET.  I'm fascinated by educational technology - and technology - and more recently have extended that interest to educational psychology.  I also like soccer refereeing, science, biking, running, and am cultivating a budding interest in sustainability and environmentalism.  And if I could become expert in one thing, it would be programming computers.
By the way, it's not too late to join up - check it out if you're interested.

item.title: The best place to do work
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This was cross-posted at ideaplay - check it out! I read a great blog post last week, "Why we (still) believe in working remotely" from a company called StackExchange, which discusses strategies for and benefits of the practice. Here's an excerpt: Stack Exchange now employs 75 people, roughly evenly split between sales (and sales ops and marketing) and product (development, ops, design, community management). The product side is where our remote working happens: we have 16 full-time remote and 18 in-office developers, sysadmins, designers, and community managers. So we are very much a hybrid team, which I’ve come to believe is the best of both worlds. The post includes super-useful sections on "What we've learned" and "How we do it" which are very relevant to us as graduate students. Part of adjusting to graduate school for me is deciding where to work - like many graduate students I was allocated an office, but I didn't use it much - I didn't use it last semester, at all, actually. I worked in the graduate student lounge, at the conference table on the 5th floor, outside in the library, at Sparty's or another coffee shop, or at home, in decreasing order of my productivity. Anyhow, this semester, and I wanted to be more productive, somehow. I felt working from home wasn't doing the trick. I was able to make my office more accommodating to work, and I've benefited from having a place in Erickson to call mine (and to leave my stuff). But back to the great blog post - I think there are many benefits to working remotely. StackExchange has explored a number of ways to work remotely better. I've found, in a bit of a different direction from which both my personal trajectory from classroom to graduate student and a general trajectory toward more remote working, that using my office has helped my productivity. Anyway, head over to the StackExchange post for more ideas.

item.title: Playing (and working) well with others
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
There are many descriptions of graduate school as a solitary endeavor. On the contrary, I've worked with colleagues and faculty more closely than at any point in my life as a student or a professional. I have repeatedly been impressed by the work ethic and skill of the individuals I am fortunate to work with in EPET.
Two colleagues described a process of writing a paper together. First, they divvy up different parts of the paper. After they write their sections, they edit one-anothers work, then edit the paper as a whole. I like this process, and feel myself drawn to it - I want to stick with and impose with process (or a related, similar process) to all of my collaboration.
But, each situation is different. And this sensation - clinging to one way of working with others - is a reflection, I believe, of my uncertainty about the process. Because of my uncertainty, I want this to work! So, this is also a question for us idea players. How do you work ("play") with others in graduate school?

item.title: New friends from the hybrid program
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This is cross-posted at ideaplay.org - check it out! In previous posts, I wrote about "Playing (and working) well with others" and more generally about "Where we work." I wrote these because my cohort and other  colleagues in EPET have been a great source of friendship. Until recently, however, I was not friends with any of the hybrid EPET students. It turns out this was a mistake, and it has fortunately been remedied. Both hybrid and face to face students have different experiences. The more I have discussed my experience with those in the hybrid program, and have heard my cohort and other face to face students engaging in similar conversations, the more I see our differences as a strength. In fact, I think this is a huge source of strength of and opportunity for our program in general. Anyhow, I am in my first "hybrid" class this semester, CEP 901B. This class specifically and the hybrid program in general make me reflect on the unique and great position in which we find ourselves. There is a lot of opportunity in this area, and just beginning to tap into the potential of friendship and collaboration with hybrid students is really exciting.
