item.title: Reflections on Attending my First Conference
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I attended my first conference this week, for the Society for Information Technology in Teacher Education (SITE) in New Orleans, LA. It was great, and like many great experiences, I happened to learn a lot. Here are some of the things I learned:
  • Treat attending the conference like a job - there were enough presentations and events (and the need to reflect on all the things happening) to be busy from the start to the end of the day
  • But have fun - my favorite memories were interacting with colleagues from my program all around the conference
  • Forget about having a normal work week - I tried to Skype into a meeting at MSU, and it didn't work not because I was not physically there, but because I was in between sessions and thinking about things related to the conference
  • This is obvious, but some quick notes I took went a long way to helping me reflect - I'll take more next time
  • Bring friends - I think a large reason I had so much fun was my EPET colleagues, and I only wish a few more could have come
[caption id="attachment_2911" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Photo from Dr. Punya Mishra (http://punya.educ.msu.edu/2013/04/01/site2013-new-orleans-2/)[/caption]

item.title: My blogging drought is over
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I used to blog a lot. Then I slowed and as the time between the present and my last post increased, I thought hard about what post would make a great return to blogging. Since I couldn't think of anything, I decided to simply write that my blogging drought is over. I hope to blog more as a way to reflect, generate ideas, and also to share my reflections and ideas.

item.title: "Rethinking Education in the Age of Technology"
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
After a busy few weeks, I picked up Rethinking Education in the Age of Technology by Collins and Halverson. This book is written in an easy-to-read way, and references are rare - in short, it's not what I'd consider a scholarly book, or what I've come to known as a scholarly book this past year. And I liked it! In chapter 2, Collins and Halverson discuss the "technology enthusiasts' argument". In chapter 3, the authors discuss the "technology skeptics' argument", then follow-up with a short list of "incompatibilities between schools and technology". These incompatibilities represent dichotomies between the enthusiasts' and skeptics' arguments. How well do the following incompatibilities hold true to your experience and/or research (bolded terms represent the enthusiasts' stance)?
  • Uniform learning versus customization
  • Teacher as expert versus diverse knowledge sources
  • Standardized high-stakes assessment versus specialization
  • Owning knowledge versus mobilizing outside resources
  • Coverage versus the knowledge explosion
  • Learning by assimilation versus learning by doing

item.title: Guilty until proven innocent - K12 "Online Public Schools"
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Every day, on the radio, TV, or web, I hear an advertisement for K12 "Online Public Schools" in Michigan. The company promises to offer entire programs of study - so students degrees will be from K12 - as well as individual courses. I don't know if K12 is a good thing or not. I do know public schools (even lower-performing public schools) can offer students more stability, safety, and consistency than anywhere else. I trust educators more than bankers (here's K12's ticker symbol - LRN - if you are interested) and I believe public schools are worth defending. The New York Times conducted an investigative report on K12 in 2011:
The New York Times has spent several months examining this idea, focusing on K12 Inc. A look at the company’s operations, based on interviews and a review of school finances and performance records, raises serious questions about whether K12 schools — and full-time online schools in general — benefit children or taxpayers, particularly as state education budgets are being slashed. Instead, a portrait emerges of a company that tries to squeeze profits from public school dollars by raising enrollment, increasing teacher workload and lowering standards.
And here's the K12 Wikipedia page:
Meanwhile, K12s business model has been acruing a record of failure.  However, the company continues to secure government contracts, due to cronyism, combined with support in state legislatures for anti-government ideology.
I don't know the people who run K12 - they could be making changes and doing the right thing for students. I'm not sure. To me, K12 is guilty until proven innocent.

item.title: My Letter from Steve Jobs
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I came across the book Letters to Steve on Amazon, and reading the first few chapters on my Kindle reminded me of the time I wrote a letter to Steve Jobs and received a response. I decided this was worth posting to my blog. I emailed Steve Jobs because I was frustrated about MobileMe becoming free soon after I paid for a year's subscription - my email was very long. To my incredulity, Jobs responded:

On Jun 11, 2011, at 3:50 PM, Steve Jobs <sjobs@apple.com> wrote:

You did cancel your account. I'll see what is possible to do at this point.

Sent from my iPhone

I heard from a customer service representative and was issued a refund. Ridiculously, I wrote back:
If you have time check the website I made for my students at www.studybio.com

Under the tab "3 Genetics" is a movie written and produced by my 10th graders in Shelby, NC using iMovie.

item.title: Winning streaks and writing streaks
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: I was pretty excited about the Detroit Tiger's 12-game winning streak last week, until it ended. At the same time, I've been thinking about the tension between being on a "streak" and taking a break, and how the open-ended structure of graduate school leaves open the question of how to figure out how to do things. This summer, I went biking and I thought about my practicum. I went hiking and I thought about my practicum. I took a shower and thought about my practicum (!!!). Okay, this has nothing to really do with the Tiger's winning streak, but stick with me here. Earlier this summer, I submitted a draft, but it didn't feel complete - there were problems. I had about two weeks between receiving feedback on that draft before submitting my final draft, and I wasn't sure my thinking would come together in time. After a marathon weekend, I submitted my proposal. When I sent it off, I felt it had problems and wasn't ready (deadlines may be the only thing that make writing ready), but I felt the important parts were there. I read it after I sent it. Then I read it again the next day. I liked what I saw. I was happy to read feedback from the faculty teaching the course, then my advisor. Afterward I had the feeling all was well - there's a difference between something that has tons of problems and isn't ready but is okay, and something that has tons of problems and isn't ready and needs to be dropped. Over the past weekend, I took "Practicum" off my to-do list (for the first time in awhile). I  didn't think about it when I was biking, hiking, or showering. It's already mades its way back onto my to-do list, but after teaching and other commitments. As a last thought, I think learning about this process - how to know a proposal is ready, how to be proud (or not ready) to present it to others, and how to take time to reflect - is as important as the practicum proposal's content. I'd like to know how my older (and current) colleagues negotiate this process too.

item.title: Goodbye (and farewell) to "summer vacation"
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: When I was a teacher I was skeptical of claims that were made about teachers' summer vacations. When you subtract the number of days after the end and prior to the beginning of the school year, professional development and planning, and any coaching responsibilities, teachers have between four and six weeks of vacation (or less); not close to "three months off". Not to say the concept of summer vacation makes sense - I think year-round school makes more sense. Now I am a graduate student, and this is my first summer - ever - I haven't had a (however abbreviated) summer vacation. Katie and I took time this past weekend to reflect on this past summer and the past year (Instagram helped): Backpacking in Nordhouse Dunes and camping at Holland State Park stood out, along with other excursions (mostly seeing friends and family). We're headed to North Carolina next week, where Katie's folks live (in Winston-Salem) and where our good friends are getting hitched (in Asheville). The purpose of this post is to say goodbye, farewell, to summer vacation. Katie and I began dating more than three years ago, became engaged more than a year ago, have lived in Michigan for approximately one year, and became married four months ago. So many changes - especially over this past year - but I've never felt more lucky and happy.

item.title: Seven Sentences about Our Trip to North Carolina
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This week we traveled to Katie's 10-year reunion (and talked with Chris Paul, who graduated with Katie) and spent time with our North Carolina family. Now we're in Asheville for the wedding of our good friends. I grew up in Michigan, and was close to attending Northern Michigan University so I could ski half the year; instead, I chose to move to North Carolina. To me, Michigan meant camping, playing soccer, friends who have known me since kindergarten, family, traditions. Now Michigan means the same things - but transformed over time and sometimes replaced by new things. North Carolina meant meeting my amazing wife, starting a career, refereeing soccer, new friends. And now North Carolina also means family and traditions.

item.title: Kevin and Kate's Wedding in Marshall, NC - Congratulations
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: The wedding of Katie's and my good friends Kevin Lane and Kate O'Mara is tonight at Kevin and Kate's farm in Marshall, NC. I've known Kevin since my first year of college and was fortunate to meet Kate a few years after. I think each is perfect for the other and am proud to call each a good friend. Congratulations, Kevin and Kate (and check out that link above to see what they have done to prepare for the big day).

item.title: Journal of Online Teaching and Learning - Special Issue on MOOCs
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: This is cross-posted at edtechcollective.org (a group blog with two friends - check it out!) The Journal of Online Teaching and Learning (JOLT) is a peer-reviewed, open-access journal. JOLT published a special issue on MOOCs today. Since JOLT is the leading publication about teaching and learning online, this represents sufficient development and interest in MOOCs to merit an issue (almost) exclusively dedicated to it. Journals such as JOLT represent the "state of the art," so in this I want to take a look at the special issue by sharing my thoughts on the two introductory articles. The first introductory article is by the executive director of Multimedia Educational Resource for Learning and Online Teaching (MERLOT), Gerald Hanley. I loved the graphic that served to introduce the article - representing the evolution from Learning Objects (LO), to Open CourseWare (OCW), to Open Textbook (OT), to Massive Open Online Course (MOOC). To Hanley, all of these are just different examples of Open Educational Resources (OER). Each of these was eventually welcomed into the educational ecosystem; but, Hanley warns that at the present time, the effects (and acceptance) of MOOCs is not yet clear. The second introductory article is by Siemens, Irvine, and Code, and represents an academic perspective on "an emerging technological and social trend." The authors highlighted that there is not (yet) enough research to suggest MOOCs should be widely adopted. I think this perspective is warranted in the present climate of "MOOC Mania". The authors also suggested that existing research about online teaching and learning has not been accounted for by MOOC providers or the media. This is a great point, and one to remember: MOOCs did not emerge from a vacuum, but are the product of a line of innovation starting with open educational resources. Note that since JOLT is open-access, anyone can view the HTML or PDF versions of any article in the journal. So take a look!

item.title: You can when you think you Kant
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Note: Reflections from attending last year's SITE conference here and EPET at SITE here.
Research takes time. I was reading the Wikipedia page for Immanuel Kant yesterday - how is that for casually dropping a name! - when I came across the amount of time Kant needed to write Critique of Pure Reason. According to Wikipedia, Critique served as a synthesis of rationality (from Wikipedia, "the emphasis on reasoning as a source of knowledge") and empiricism (from Wikipedia, "the emphasis on observational evidence as a source of knowledge"). Again, according to Wikipedia, Kant "felt that reason could remove his skepticism" about the existence of ideas not evident in experience. So, in 1770, "Kant isolated himself. He resisted friends' attempts to bring him out of his isolation."In 1778, having not published anything for eight years, Kant wrote:
My great thanks, to my well-wishers and friends, who think so kindly of me as to undertake my welfare, but at the same time a most humble request to protect me in my current condition from any disturbance.
In 1781, "Kant emerged from his silence . . . the result was the Critique of Pure Reason . . . now uniformly recognized as one of the greatest works in the history of philosophy." It took Kant 12 years, during which Kant, "isolated," did not publish anything! Something to think about the next time I am struggling with a two paragraph proposal to present at the Society for Information Technology and Teacher Education (SITE) conference.

item.title: 'da UP
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Katie and I joined my folks in 'da UP - that is, the Upper Peninsula of Michigan - the weekend before last. We camped at Tahquamenon Falls and visited Lake Superior (Katie and I are at Whitefish point here): The last time I was in 'da UP was camping in 2000 with my family (my brother Aaron and me goofing around on a trail here):

item.title: On Sushi Chefs and Pragmatism
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I have recently been thinking about research questions, approaches, and methods, and am focusing back on research questions as a way to find out about what I am most interested. To begin, two books have pushed my thinking:
  • The Mind's New Science (Howard Gardner) about cognitive psychology
  • The Person and the Situation (Lee Ross and Richard Nisbett) about social psychology
Next, a conversation with my colleague Luke was really helpful. Luke suggested I direct my attention to research questions. Taking a cognitive or social psychological approach (or being a cognitive or social psychologist) is less important than knowing what questions I want to ask. Approaches and methods follow from research questions. Then, I heard an interview on a public radio station with a sushi chef. The chef discussed how the sushi is one of the rare occasions a diner can watch his or her meal being prepared. The chef tailors the experience for diners, so the office worker may be served something "vinegary, to stimulate the appetite," whereas the person who was outside all day may be served something salty. Over the course of the meal, the chef seeks to bring together the experiences of different diners, so different diners' experiences are unique, but similar. The chef brings together the diners and the ingredients. Being concerned with research questions, approaches, and methods (don't laugh!), this reminded me of pragmatism. In terms of the nature of knowledge, the pragmatist is most concerned with what knowledge is most practical. This contrasts the view of the rationalist, who is concerned with reason as the source of knowledge, and that of the empiricist, who is concerned with experience as the source of knowledge. If you ask a pragmatist about the nature of knowledge, the response may be a shrug. The question is not important; whatever knowledge is most practical is important. Last year (around this time) I became concerned about the approaches researchers took - behaviorist, sociocultural, or cognitive. I was drawn to research that explicitly discussed these approaches, and rebelled against other research. Over time this issue became less important to me; exemplary research may draw from, say, both sociocultural and cognitive perspectives. Recently, I have become concerned (and wrote a post) about the philosophical traditions associated with behaviorist, sociocultural, and cognitive approach. Finally, a short conversation pushed my thinking. These concerns about approaches or philosophy are critical - whether and how a student changes over time through development, behavior, experience, or a combination of each of is important. But thinking about the types of questions I want to begin to answer through my research questions is helpful, and possibly more productive. Doing so does not mean "big" questions about approaches and methods are less important, but that approaches and methods follow from research questions. This post covered a lot of ground - from research questions, approaches, and methods, to sushi chefs and pragmatism! In a later post I will sketch some research questions I would like to begin to answer.

item.title: Research Methods in Educational Technology
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Educational technology is a diverse field - check out the recent publication Handbook of Research for Educational Communications and Technology for a survey of the diversity of educational technology. Psychology is also diverse - see the APA Handbook of Educational Psychology, which comprises three volumes and is 1843 pages. Recently I have looked at "context" - its meaning and role in research - as part of an interest in the abilities of people from diverse backgrounds to learn with technology. That interest is too broad to become a research question; a specific approach is needed.  To that end, here is my take on how particular approaches in psychology and other fields address "context," as well as common methods and scholars. A caveat - these descriptions are relatively superficial (and debatable) and reflect my limited but growing understanding of the field.

Social psychology

Context: A product of the presence of others (social context) "Behavior is a function of the person and the situation . . . The social context creates potent forces producing or constraining behavior" (Ross & Nisbett, 2011, p. 9). "The impact of any "objective" stimulus depends upon the personal and subjective meaning that the actor attaches to that situation . . . the social psychological and behaviorist traditions parted company long ago over [this] issue construal" (Ross & Nisbett, 2011, p. 11). "Individual psyches, as well as collectives . . . must be understand in a state of tension . . . No simple mechanistic laws relating particular stimuli to particular contexts are possible, given that both are always embedded in dynamic contexts that alter and constrain their effects (Ross & Nisbett, 2011, p. 13). Methods: Experimental, sometimes in laboratory settings Scholars: Kurt Lewin, Lee Ross, Richard Nisbett

Cognitive psychology

Context: Deemphasized "Though mainstream cognitive scientists do not necessarily bear any animus against the affective realm, against the context that surrounds any action or thought, or against historical or cultural analyses, in practice they attempt to factor out these elements to the maximum extent possible . . . This may be a question of practicality: if one were to take into account these individualizing and phenomenalistic elements, cognitive science might become impossible" (Gardner, 1987, p. 41). Methods: Experimental, sometimes in laboratory settings Scholars: Herbert Simon, Howard Gardner, Daniel Kahneman

Behaviorism

Context: Deterministic Individuals do not act upon mental representations, plans, or ideas; from a behaviorist perspective, "individuals were seen as passive reflectors of various forces and factors in the environment" (Gardner, 1987, p. 12). Specifically, functional contextualism is "an extension and contextualistic interpretation of B.F. Skinner's radical behaviorism, and emphasizes the importance of predicting and influencing psychological events (including thoughts, feelings, and behaviors) by focusing on manipulable variables in their context" (Functional contextualism, 2013, para. 1). Methods: Experimental, sometimes in laboratory settings Scholars: John Watson, Edward Thorndike, B.F. Skinner

Situated cognition

Context: Relation between individuals and the environment, which are fundamentally different; site and stimulus of improvisatory action This perspective focuses on study of individuals acting in an everyday setting (Lave, 1988); "the unit of analysis is thus not the individual, not the environment, but a relation between the two" (Nardi, 1996, p. 36).  "Situated cognition demphasizes study of more durable, stable phenomena that persist across situations" and empirical accounts "are highly particularistic" (Nardi, 1996, p. 36). Methods: Detailed descriptions of individuals acting in a setting; subjective experience is deemphasized Scholars: Jean Lave, William Clancey, Lucy Suchman

Distributed cognition

Context: Relation between individuals and artifacts, which are equals in an interactive system; partial site and stimulus of improvisatory action The unit of analysis is "a cognitive system composed of individuals and the artifacts they use . . . distributed cognition moves the unit of analysis to the system and finds its center of gravity in the function of a system" (Nardi, 1996, p. 38-39).  "Distributed cognition is concerned with structure - representations inside and outside the head - and the transformations these structures undergo" (Nardi, 1996, p. 39). Methods: Similar to cognitive psychology, but in participants' everyday settings and artifacts Scholars: Edward Hutchins, Gavriel Salomon

Activity theory

Context: An activity; partial site and stimulus of improvisatory action The unit of analysis is an activity which is comprised of a subject (a person or group), object (an objective or goal), actions (object-focused processes), and operations (the way an activity is carried out) (Nardi, 1996).  These constituents may change as as conditions change, and artifacts (instruments, signs, language, machines, etc.) mediate activities.  "Activity theory . . . proposes a very specific notion of context: the activity itself is the context . . . Context is constituted through the enactment of an activity involving people and artifacts" (Nardi, 1996, p. 38).  "Context is both internal to people- involving specific objects and goals - and, at the same time, external to people, involving artifacts, other people, and specific settings" (Nardi, 1996, p. 38). Methods: Attention to individuals acting in a setting, over a time frame long enough to understand participants' objectives for acting, with varied data collection techniques focused on subjective experience Scholars: Aleksei Leontiev, Bonnie Nardi

Cultural psychology

Context: Culture "The main tenet of cultural psychology is that mind and culture are inseparable and mutually constitutive" (Cultural psychology, 2013). "Individuals' development is a product of social interactions that transmit culture over time" (Cultural-historical perspective, 2013).  Methods: Diverse; qualitative Scholars: Lev Vygotsky, Michael Cole, Kenneth Rogoff

Anthropology

Context: Unique to individuals and groups of individuals, and comparisons across contexts facilitates understanding of similarities and differences between individuals and groups of individuals This perspective is distinguished from other social sciences by "its emphasis on cross-cultural comparisons, long-term in-depth examination of context, and the importance it places on participant-observation or experiential immersion in the area of research" (Anthropology, 2013). Methods: Ethnography; detailed, "thick" descriptions of contexts Scholars: Margaret Mead, Clifford Geertz

Bioecological Model

Context: Hierachical, partially deterministic of individual development "Individuals develop over time through reciprocal interactions with the environment, specifically through interactions with microsystems, mesosystems, exosystems, and macrosystems" (Bioecological model, 2013). Methods: Longitudinal, to investigate the effects of different contextual factors over time; in the natural environment Scholar: Urie Bronfenbrenner, Stephen Ceci [facebook] [retweet]

item.title: Similarities between early machine learning programs and massive open online courses (MOOCS)
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I borrowed Automatic Teaching (1959) to learn about the history of educational technology.  I was surprised by similarities between early machine learning programs and today's massive open online courses (MOOCs). Here is an excerpt from a chapter in Automatic Teaching on an early machine learning program in college psychology:
A program was written for approximately one quarter of a course in Behavioral Science.  The program covered material similar to that covered by about 200 pages of the text Science and Human Behavior.  This required 48 sets of "lessons," each usually containing 29 frames or "items."  When all machine work was completed the students were required to fil out a questionnaire.  They reported rather favorable impressions of the machine work . . . The subject matter was ordered so as to provide a gradual progression with a minimum of errors.  Lists of terms and examples were carefully prepared to assure the student would be made able to converse about the subject matter in as wide a context as possible. James G. Holland, 1959, A Teaching Machine Program in Psychology
And here is an article about the MOOC provider Coursera:
Within the central instruction module, snap quizzes — with instant online grading — typically break up instructors’ material every few minutes. That’s meant to ensure that students grasp key concepts and aren’t just blinking idly as new concepts stream past. Meanwhile, students keep participating between formal sessions, through various online forums and chat groups with their peers. Forbes, 2013, Coursera Hits 4 Million Students -- And Triples Its Funding

item.title: From life science to social science
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: Until recently, I have not thought about what it means to be a social scientist. My undergraduate degree was in biology, with coursework in other natural sciences; despite attending a liberal arts university (UNC Asheville), social science classes I took in introductory and educational psychology were interesting but did not affect my core. Consequently, I graduated knowing about social science without having tried what it is to think like a social scientist. My wife Katie and my friend Sam have impressed upon me recently the value of social science research in discussions of social science phenomena (feminism and qualitative methodologies, respectively) in a similar but different way than my brother impressed me with his quantitative natural science research. I have learned about the history and approaches to research social science fields take over the past year-and-a-half. There is not a class to take to learn to be a social scientist. In short, I have learned social scientists conduct scientific research on individuals and groups of individuals, sometimes in ways different and other times pretty similar to natural scientists.

item.title: Stop Focusing Research on Things, Start Focusing Research on Problems
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: David Wiley wrote a blog post about a conference presentation by Tom Reeves on things and problems in educational technology research. Specifically, stop focusing research on things - even exciting things like massive open online courses and learning analytics - and start focusing research on problems, like lack of literacy, poor motivation, and poverty. Reading something at the right time crystallizes ideas in formation. Reading this post did just that for me with concern to focusing on a research topic.

item.title: The meaning of a Rose Bowl win
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Before coming to MSU, I grew up a University of Michigan fan, then went to North Carolina and forgot about U of M, MSU, and college football. I have memories of cheering U of M (and Charles Woodson - with Tom Brady as the backup quarterback) in the 1998 Rose Bowl.
MSU's win in the Rose Bowl yesterday meant a lot of different things, none of which I'm qualified to quantify, which has not stopped my attempt to do that. To the B1G and Michigan, it meant a defining win. To Spartans, it meant a lot of pride, To the team, it meant completion. To my parents, it meant donning MSU shirts.
To me, a Rose Bowl win meant a bit of what it meant for the B1G and Michigan, Spartans, and the team, mixed together with my decision to come to MSU and my home, and for Katie to come with me.
Go Green!

item.title: How to read a lot of books?
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
You have to read books in graduate school. In graduate school in education, everyone has read some Dewey. But how about Piaget, and Vygotsky, and Skinner, and Papert, and Kahneman, and even Pinker? There are many books to read, and books (*used books) are easier to buy on Amazon then read. How to read a lot of books? Don't. That is the heart of the message from a post on the blog gradhacker. The author, Shira Lurie, listed four tips for how to read a book in two hours or less. Here is one I found especially helpful:

2. DO NOT begin at the beginning; do not end at the end. INSTEAD, read for argument.

Resist the temptation to start on the first page and see how far you get. Tailor your reading to what you wish to get out of the book; in most cases, this is the author’s argument. Begin by carefully reading the title, the back of the book, the table of contents, the introduction, and the conclusion – all places where the author reveals his/her argument and its structure. This step will hopefully reinforce the information you gleaned from the book reviews.

There are times (many times) when it is appropriate and best to read an entire book, such as when the book is closely related to a research interest or project, or, of course, when the book is read for pleasure.

Shira's post highlights how there are also times when it is appropriate to treat books as references in order to get more reading done.

Read the rest of the post on gradhacker.

item.title: Dispatches from #edcampLansing
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I attended Edcamp Lansing (#edcampLansing) yesterday, which was on the campus of MSU. Edcamp is an "unconference," best described on the Edcamp Lansing website:
If you’ve never been to an Edcamp, read on. It’s a free, single-day “unconference” that’s organized by educators, for educators. Whether you work in K-12, higher ed, or outside the system, Edcamp is where you come to share, learn, and discuss the issues and tools most on people’s minds. To keep sessions as relevant, topical, and democratic as possible, we don’t book presenters ahead of time. Attendees show up in the morning and decide for themselves what they want to meet about. If you want to lead a session, sign up in an empty slot on the public schedule, with your session title and name. That’s it.
The schedule was constructed in the registration period, during which participants added session ideas to a whiteboard, and at the opening session, during which participants described sessions and shouted ideas for additional sessions. Here is the Google Docs version of the schedule. I am thankful for the opportunity to learn from and be inspired by those I met (or got to spend time with) yesterday. My tweet after two sessions captures what I experienced:

At #edcampLansing - incredible opportunity to learn about what is working in edu

— Josh Rosenberg (@jrosenberg6432) January 25, 2014

item.title: What the EPET Social Media Council is up to
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: A recent discussion with Punya - during which Punya joked that the name "Social Media Council" was too official-sounding - prompted us to issue Punya the first-ever Social Media Council official sanction.  If you are curious, the Social Media Council currently consists of John Bell, William Cain, Spencer Greenhalgh, Ginny Hiltz, Rohit Mehta, Josh Rosenberg, Tracy Russo, and Colin Terry. Here's our page on the EPET Hub. We have worked together for approximately 1.5 years coordinating social media platforms for our program. Based on some of the ongoing lessons we learned we are presenting a paper at the Society for Information and Teacher Education conference in March. Specifically, we are talking about six best practices: 1) establish why, 2) establish how, 3) be authentic, 4) understand privacy, 5) coordinate channels, and 6) engage volunteers. Here's a PDF with a bunch more. The group of people involved will change over time. We fervently welcome anyone in our program who wishes to join the effort; if everyone in the program is part of the council, that's great (we think)! Contact us at epetsmc@gmail.com if you have any questions, news or events to share, or if you would like to come to our next meeting (it will also always be listed on the EPEThub calendar. We would love to have you.

item.title: Slides for my presentation at today's brownbag
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
In my research, I focus on how social and cultural factors affect how individuals teach and learn, so that I can understand and design learning environments that support learning with technology for all students, and in particular disadvantaged students. This is important because how youth access and use technology leads to different educational outcomes, which are important with respect to how youth develop personal and occupational interests that are individually and socially valuable. Context, or the social and cultural factors that surround individuals, is important to the study of learning and development. The developers of TPACK - and others - have described context as an important part of the framework. However, context is often overlooked, and what researchers mean by context is confusing. In this study, I investigated the inclusion of context as part of TPACK, as well as the meaning of context, among publications that make use of the framework. In general, attention to context both improves the understanding of theory and research interventions, and can make research more relevant to practice. In that spirit, this study contributes to the further theoretical understanding of TPACK and to recent attempts to develop and assess TPACK in authentic teaching and learning contexts. Here are slides for my presentation at today's brownbag.
Brownbag_Presentation 2_17 from Josh Rosenberg

item.title: Slides for my presentation at #MobileMSU
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg

Here are the slides for my presentation at #MobileMSU:
#MobileMSU Action Research from Josh Rosenberg

item.title: Design-Based Research and Context
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I read an article that introduced design-based research as a methodology characterized by the iterative design of an intervention or learning environment and empirical research. Design-based research is important, particularly to learning sciences researchers. I noticed that the context of some intervention or learning environment was emphasized, and decided to highlight some of the ways. 1. Attention to context connects research and practice: Educational research that is detached from practice may not account for the influence of contexts, the emergent and complex nature of outcomes, and the incompleteness of knowledge about which factors are relevant for prediction. (p. 5) 2. The design of the intervention or learning environment and the steps taken during its design are an outcome: Because the intervention as enacted is a product of the context in which it is implemented, the intervention is the outcome (or at least an outcome) in an important sense. (p. 5) 3. It is important to understand the effects of context with concern to issues related to teaching and learning: Randomized trials are not necessarily the appropriate end goal of our research approach; we do not understand issues of context well enough yet to guarantee that randomized trials are the best means to answer the questions we care about.  (p. 6) 4. Paying attention to context can contribute to contextualized theories: The value of attending to context is not simply that it produces a better understanding of an intervention, but also that it can lead to improved theoretical accounts of teaching and learning. (p. 7) 5. Pay attention to context can contribute to better implementation of policies: As a field, educational research must develop better theories of the elements of context that matter for the nature of learning and for the implications of policy for local educational practices.  (p. 8)
The article is available here. The Design-Based Research Collective. (2003). Design-based research: An emerging paradigm for educational inquiry. Educational Researcher, 32(1), 5-8.

item.title: Notes from two TPACK literature reviews
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
Two literature reviews about TPACK have recently been published - in Educational Technology and Society (Chai, Koh, & Tsai, 2013) and the Journal of Computer Assisted Learning (Voogt, Fisser, Roblin, Tondeur, & van Braak, 2012). Taken together, the following needs for further research were identified:
  1. The nature of TPACK in specific subject domains
  2. The assessment of TPACK in specific subject domains
  3. The relationship between TPACK, teacher practical knowledge, and teacher beliefs
  4. The design of technological environments based upon TPACK and the effects of different contexts
  5. Student outcomes as a result of teaching and learning informed by TPACK
  6. The connection between TPACK and other theoretical frameworks
In the remainder of this post I discuss, for each, the need, purpose, sample, methods of analysis, results, and discussion.

Voogt, Fisser, Roblin, Tondeur, & van Braak (2012)

Need and Purpose Increased interest in TPACK warranted a systematic evaluation of the evolution of TPACK and its applications. The purpose of this literature review was to investigate the theoretical basis and practical use of TPACK. Sample and Method 61 journal articles (44 empirical, 17 theoretical) made up the sample. The 61 articles in the sample were pre-coded along three dimensions: 1) consistency, 2) data collection, and 3) data analyses. Six articles exhibited poor quality and were not analyzed further, resulting in 55 articles about TPACK (44 empirical and 11 theoretical) subjected to further analysis. These articles were coded for 1) characteristics of the study (research questions, target group, etc.), and 2) contributions with respect to theory and practice. The contributions with respect to theory were coded further along the following sub-dimensions: 1) development of the concept, 2) views on TK, 3) development of TPACK as a concept in specific subject domains, and 4) TPACK and teacher beliefs. The contributions with respect to practice were coded further along the following sub-dimensions: 1) measuring TPACK and 2) strategies for developing TPACK. Results Theoretical Contributions: 1. Development of the concept: Three different conceptualizations of TPACK have been presented in prior research: 1) TPACK as extended PCK, 2) TPACK as a unique body of knowledge, and 3) TPACK as the interplay between the three domains of knowledge and their intersections. The first two conceptualizations represent transformative views (TPACK as greater than the sum of its constituent bodies of knowledge) while the last represents an integrative view (TPACK as the product of its constituent bodies of knowledge). 2. TK has been described in different ways, from instrumental (focused on technological tools) and functional (focused on the purposes achieved through the use of technological tools) perspectives. 3. TPACK has not been studied significantly in specific subject domains. 4. Teacher beliefs, about technology and about pedagogy, have been shown to influence the development of TPACK. Practical Contributions: 1. Few studies have provided a clear description of the instrument used to measure TPACK. 2. Active involvement in a technology-enhanced lesson or course design is the main strategy to develop TPACK. Discussion There is a need for further research in 1) specific subject domains, 2) further research on the relationship between TPACK, teacher practical knowledge, and teacher beliefs, and 3) understanding TPACK in specific subject domains facilitates the assessment of teachers' TPACK.

Chai, Koh, and Tsai (2013)

Need and Purpose Research about TPACK exhibited promise, but there was a need to review and assess the directions of current TPACK research. The purpose of this literature review was to consolidate emerging trends, findings, and issues generated in TPACK research, and identify gaps in the literature.  Sample and Methods 74 journal articles about TPACK made up the sample. Data were coded along four dimensions: 1) basic data about the publication (year, journal, etc.), 2) research methods (data collected, method of analysis, etc.), 3) content analysis (what specific knowledge was developed with respect to technology, pedagogy, and content) and 4) discussion (issues discussed, future directions, etc.). Results 1. Basic data: Since 2005, there has been a growing interest in applying the TPACK framework; ~65% of studies were conducted in North America, followed by Europe (~17%), then the Asia-Pacific region (~18%). 64% of the articles were published in educational technology journals, with other articles published in cross discipline, subject based, and teacher education journals. 2. Research methods: 55 of the 74 publications (74%) of the articles were data driven (or empirical), with the remainder being theoretical, worked example, or editorial papers. Among the 55 data driven publications, 42%  were qualitative, 18% quantitative, and 15% mixed methods. The most common research methods were intervention studies, followed by case studies. 3. Content analysis: 51 of the 54 (94%) of the publications advocated constructivist-oriented pedagogy, such as project-based or inquiry-based learning. Subject-general technology were used in 34 (63%) studies, while subject-specific technologies were used in 20 (37%) studies. Results from the data coded for the "Discussion" dimension were identified in the discussion of the paper. Discussion There are three areas of need for further research: 1) the design of technological environments based upon TPACK, 2) student outcomes as a result of teaching and learning informed by TPACK, and 3) the connection between TPACK and other theoretical frameworks. References Chai, C. S., Koh, J. H. L., & Tsai, C. C. (2013). A Review of Technological Pedagogical Content Knowledge. Educational Technology & Society, 16(2), 31-51. Retrieved from http://www.ifets.info/abstract.php?art_id=1349 Voogt, J., Fisser, P., Pareja Roblin, N., Tondeur, J., & van Braak, J. (2013). Technological pedagogical content knowledge–a review of the literature. Journal of Computer Assisted Learning, 29(2), 109-121. Retrieved from http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2729.2012.00487.x

item.title: Mobile learning in the classroom webinar
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: The MAET program has a webinar series called MAET Bridge (more here and here).  and I was part of a webinar today on mobile learning in the classroom with Candace Marcotte (@canmarcotte), Brett Koph (@brettkopf), and Sandra Sawaya (@sandrasawaya). I think it was an interesting talk of which I appreciated being part. The archive of the webinar is available here: http://bridge.educ.msu.edu/.

item.title: What we learn when we engage in design-based research
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
According to Edelson (2002) conventional research has the purpose of testing theories: a theory is developed, principles for designs are derived from the theory, the guidelines are enacted through an intervention, and then the intervention is assessed. In contrast, design-based research has goals of both making design decisions in the best way possible with respect to the goals, needs, or opportunities at hand, and given the constraints of the design context, and to develop useful, generalizable theories of teaching and learning. In the remainder of this post I paraphrase - for my benefit, and if you're interested in the methodology yours - what Edelson (2002) said about design-based research with respect to 1) the decisions involved and 2) the types of theories it can help develop,  3) its difference from simple design, and 4) reasons for doing it. 1. Decisions in design-based research Three types of design decisions are made in design-based research; these decisions are not necessarily explicit, conscious, or formally articulated.
  1.  The design procedure specifies the processes and the people that are involved in the development of a design.
  2. The problem analysis characterizes the goals, need, or opportunity that a design is intended to address together with the challenges, constraints, and opportunities presented by the design context.
  3. The design solution describes the resulting design.
2. Theories from design-based research Each of the three design decisions has a corresponding type of theory that design-based research develops.
  1. A design methodology is a generalized design procedure, and characterizes the process rather than the product of design.
  2. A domain theory is a generalization of some portion of a problem analysis, and might be about learners and how they learn, teachers and how they teach, or learning environments and how they influence teaching and learning. There are two types of domain theories, context theories, which characterize the challenges and opportunities presented by a class of design contexts, and outcomes theories, which characterize a set of outcomes associated with some intervention.
  3. A design framework is a generalized design solution, and is a collection of coherent design guidelines for a particular class of design challenge.
3. From design to design-based research Four features distinguish design-based research from simple design, and advocate that lessons learned from design must apply beyond the specific context in which they were learned.
  1.  For a design-based research program to yield useful results, it must be informed by prior research and be guided by research goals.
  2. The design process must be thoroughly and systematically documented.
  3. Formative evaluation is critical in design research because it can identify inadequacies in the problem analysis, the solution, and the design procedure that cannot be exposed through analytical processes alone.
  4. Through a retrospective analysis, the designer-researcher treats the design problem, solution, and processes as instances of more general classes, and in doing so, must be alert to elements of the design that can generalize to a useful range of situations.
4. Why engage in design-based research There are three reasons to engage in design-based research.
  1.  Design-based research provides a productive method of theory development. It does this by 1) requiring the theory to be fully specified, 2) the design process reveals theoretical inconsistencies, and 3) the goal-directed nature of design provides a natural focus for theory development.
  2. Design-based research leads to useful results. Specifically, results that speak directly to the design of activities, materials, and systems will be the most useful result of design based research.
  3. Design-based research directly involves researchers in the improvement of education. Educational researchers are in a unique position to construct solutions to meet needs of the educational system, because they have the freedom to explore innovative designs free from the market considerations that drive traditional educational designers.
Reference Edelson, D.C. (2002). What we learn when we engage in design. The Journal of the Learning Sciences, 11(1), 105-121. Retrieved from http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1207/S15327809JLS1101_4#.UyESkfSwKkY

item.title: What I learned this school year
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded: The spring semester is almost complete, and with it my second year of doctoral study. I reflected on some of the most important things I learned, and wanted to briefly share them here. First, I spent a lot of time thinking, reading, and writing about context, or the conditions around individuals and groups of individuals. I think that when conceptions of context from psychology and educational psychology are applied to educational technology, very concrete recommendations emerge. Taking context seriously in educational technology means that learners use technology not in isolation, but in a rich setting of social interactions, resources, scaffolds, and supports. In short, integrating context into accounts means taking a half-step back to include this setting in analyses. Second, the more the setting (and its social interactions, resources, scaffolds, and supports) is included in analyses, the harder it is to consider learners and technologies as separate from a content area. Different content areas, such as social studies and mathematics, afford and constrain technology use in unique ways. In short, an important part of learners' context is disciplinary content. Third, taking context into account in analyses and theories of teaching and learning with technology is important, but how contextualized accounts or theories align with curriculum, instruction, and assessment is also important. What does contextualized, relevant curriculum look like? Instruction that takes into account learners' diverse contexts? What does a contextualized assessment item even mean? I do not have answers to these questions, but I think one key is to conceptualize learning as behavioral and conceptual change, and as something different: as changing participation in communities of learners, and more importantly, do-ers. Fourth, engaging with the differences between real-world contexts is difficult to do without working with those who know best the complexity and messiness of teaching and learning with technology: teachers. I think the formation of partnerships between researchers and teachers is important with concern to conducting research that advances both theory and practice. Thanks friends and family for your support the past two years.

item.title: EPET at SITE, 2014
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
This post originally appeared on Dr. Mishra’s blog, then on the ideaplay blog. SITE2014 (the annual conference of the Society of Information Technology in Teacher Education) is being held in Jacksonville, Florida starting the 17th of March. As always, the Educational Psychology and Educational Technologyprogram at MSU has a significant presence at the conference. This includes presentations and symposia organized by faculty, graduate students and graduates of our program. item.title: Some thoughts about how and why we do the research we do
item.dc:creator: joshuarosenberg
item.content:encoded:
I overheard the following statement last week:  "You have to balance what you want to do, with what you said you would do, with what the field needs." I reflected and think this is relevant to the research we do as graduate students. There are three parts with concern to how and why we do research:
  1. What you want to do
  2. What is required
  3. What the field needs
In the context of a class assignment (like a literature review to gap in the literature essay), this means we have to balance what we want to do (change the world!), with the requirements for the assignment (connected to the course content in some ways; 10 pages), with some area of the literature - and gap - that has been identified as significant to others, perhaps identified through a conversation with the professor or an advisor. In the context of a research proposal (like for a practicum), this means we have to balance what we want to do (still try to change the world!), with program requirements and expectations, with a research question that you, in conjunction with your advisor, deem to contribute in a minor way to what the field ways. In the context of a dissertation proposal, this means we have to balance what we want to do (change a targeted part of the world), with program requirements and expectations, as well as funding and other practical constraints, with what the field needs. I think this is a helpful way of thinking about how and why we do the research we do. To do the research we want to do that is what the field needs, but somehow does not meet what is required (or in the context of a fellowship/grant is what we said we would do), to do the research that meets requirements and is what the field needs but is not interesting and meaningful, or to do the research that is what we want to do and meets the requirements but is not what the field needs, is less than ideal.
